author: {profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/builtforadventure79, first_name=Mindy and Melissa, ID=2.00445758E8, avatar_URL=https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/8713309a8255b1d61f29305043dcdefb?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, URL=http://b4apodcast.wordpress.com, login=builtforadventure79, ip_address=false, last_name=, name=Builtforadventure, site_visible=true, nice_name=builtforadventure79, site_ID=1.88453642E8, email=false}
title: Highs n Lows
content:
Where do I even begin?

Y’all.

It’s been like a very long minute since I blogged here. And if I’m not mistaken the last blog was even about highs and lows. But it seems like that is just the norm here lately.

My poor daughter lost her pup of 15 years. Like over half her life that dog has been by her side. And it was a tragic ending. One that I was not there for. Talk about a heart break x 2. Luckily we have a kick as neighbor who stepped up and was Mama a day. So much gratitude.

Then the very next week, our Storm girl decided to put a hole in her neck. Thanks chick. Another vet bill. 😥. Luckily it was an easy fix and she healed like a champ, barley a scar. Thanks Jay and Odell, y’all rock.

Then the very next week. My poor BFF and the other part of this B4A team, lost her heart horse. Meg being the rock she is went to help her while yet again, I could not be there. Got her foot stomped on and had to be the rock. Poor Melissa. Oh how she is going to miss Her Daisy May.

Then maybe 2 months later, our Poncho dog gets sick out of nowhere. Vet visit it was. Within 2 weeks, my poor poor sweet girl had to say goodbye yet again. Thank you Mark for being there. I could have been, but she said no. She is so strong.

It has been a whirl wind of junk. My heart breaks because over the losses. My it is happy that I have raised such a strong solid woman. I have my moments of weakness. More often than not, so I can’t take all the credit. But I will take most of it. 🤫

How do you all deal with so many heartbreaks all at once? How do you keep moving forward when it seems like you are falling apart? Some days I just wanted to crawl in a hole and not come out. Other days I wanted to move til I couldn’t no more. The more I could move, the slower my mind got.

It is not easy being a Mom, wife, best friend, animal lover. It’s not easy being tender hearted. (I only look like I’m not to hide that I actually am)

Fortunately life is still moving forward. So we have to learn to move with it. Just do t move so fast that you forget to grieve. Take the moment to feel the lows and then you will eventually learn how to feel the highs.

title: “The world is so big, but I still meet you”
content:
}" data-image-title="IMG20220515170457" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://thestoriesofwind.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img20220515170457.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://thestoriesofwind.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img20220515170457.jpg?w=1024" src="https://thestoriesofwind.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img20220515170457.jpg?w=1024" alt="" class="wp-image-254" srcset="https://thestoriesofwind.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img20220515170457.jpg?w=1024 1024w, https://thestoriesofwind.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img20220515170457.jpg?w=2048 2048w, https://thestoriesofwind.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img20220515170457.jpg?w=150 150w, https://thestoriesofwind.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img20220515170457.jpg?w=300 300w, https://thestoriesofwind.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img20220515170457.jpg?w=768 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" />

My backpack was full of memories of youth

to embark on the journey of growth

Just come to this crossroads

You do not need to see me off, just go home

See you and goodbye by a word “See you again”

All the memories in the past will not return

When you feel lost,

believe yourself as I have always believed in you

The world is so big, but I still meet you

How many times crazy is how many times naive

Chase the dream together

One day we will meet again in a faraway countryside

The world is so big, but I still meet you

Go through many times together, four seasons, spring, summer, autumn, winter

Far away from the South to the North

Do not forget the love between us

The world is so big, but I still meet you

How many times crazy is how many times naive

Chase the dream together

One day we will meet again in a faraway countryside

The world is so big, but I still meet you

Go through many times together, four seasons, spring, summer, autumn, winter

Far away from the South to the North

Do not forget the love between us

“世界这么大还是遇见你”

title: The WORDLE Philosophy
content:
}" data-image-title="The WORDLE Philosophy" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="

The WORDLE Philosophy

" data-medium-file="https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=300" data-large-file="https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=1024" src="https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=1024" alt="" class="wp-image-1768" srcset="https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=1024 1024w, https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=2048 2048w, https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=150 150w, https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=300 300w, https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=768 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" />

Ever since my brain first began to consciously evaluate my ever-changing surroundings, I have always managed to find deeper meanings that confide within the peculiarly simple things across our daily lives. An intricate belief, like the sturdy roots of an old tree, is embedded inside me that even from non-complex and monotonous things in life, we can learn and cultivate something entirely good, something that can help us live a considerably better life. How astonishing!

And this strong belief has led me today to discover a thing quite astounding and truly extraordinary confiding within a much simpler outer shell in disguise.

Hiding beneath the seeming tip that is WORDLE, lies a mountain of possibly life-altering philosophy, which when mimicked correctly in our own lives, can truly help us achieve our goals and dreams: The WORDLE Philosophy!

But before I begin relaying all the papers on this philosophy, we first need to know what it is the philosophy of. It is time to ask:

What is WORDLE?

Those familiar with the game of WORDLE, feel free to skip this part and head to the next section.

WORDLE is a daily word puzzle game that one can play simply in a web browser (no additional apps required). The game itself is a breeze to get hang of, a big reason why it is particularly trending around the world. The simplest rule of playing states; we have to guess the word of the day in no more than six attempts. It will always be a random five-letter word. Hence, the attempt-grid will invariably consist of a 5×6 matrix of squares, and would look like this:

}" data-image-title="img_20220404_114901__01-01" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220404_114901__01-01.jpeg?w=300" data-large-file="https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220404_114901__01-01.jpeg?w=1024" src="https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220404_114901__01-01.jpeg?w=1024" alt="" class="wp-image-1771" srcset="https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220404_114901__01-01.jpeg?w=1024 1024w, https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220404_114901__01-01.jpeg?w=2048 2048w, https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220404_114901__01-01.jpeg?w=150 150w, https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220404_114901__01-01.jpeg?w=300 300w, https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220404_114901__01-01.jpeg?w=768 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" />

Now, when we enter the initial attempt; our first word upon this grid, there are three things that one can find in return indicated by the color change of the letters.

  1. Grey/Black – These signify the letters which are not present in the final word.
  2. Yellow – These hint at the letters which are existing in the answer, but not in the current position that we have entered them.
  3. Mighty Green! – As the nature of this color suggests, these letters indicate being at the right spot and are obviously present in the final word to find.

As there are only six attempts that one can make, the ultimate goal of this game is for us to try different calculated words based upon the intricate feedback provided (green, yellow, or black) and find the eventual answer within the given 5×6 grid.

Being a daily word game, it resets and changes its answer every 24 hours. So, if any of you haven’t tried this even once, I would urge you to try today’s rendition. Once tried, do come back here, so we can finally learn how to use this game as a guiding book for achieving our true goals in life!

Here’s the link –

https://www.nytimes.com/games/wordle/

After we have familiarized ourselves with this word puzzle, we can then decisively ask,

What the heck is this WORDLE Philosophy? 

The WORDLE Philosophy

}" data-image-title="The WORDLE Philosophy" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="

The WORDLE Philosophy

" data-medium-file="https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=300" data-large-file="https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=1024" src="https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=1024" alt="" class="wp-image-1768" srcset="https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=1024 1024w, https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=2048 2048w, https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=150 150w, https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=300 300w, https://scholarlyscribblerhome.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_20220405_105054__01-02.jpeg?w=768 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" />

Let’s take the help of a short instance to understand.

“You did today’s WORDLE yet?”

“Oh, no. I forgot!” I replied to my good friend.

“Today’s word is very tricky! Took me all of my six tries.”

“Oh,” my eyes widened in response. “Let me try it as well,” and within a flash, I was found staring blankly at the familiar empty square grid of 5×6.
Today’s word is very tricky.
My mind remembered, contemplating deeply on what the first try should be. Although I had several common words ready to barge, the term tricky was beginning to mess with my head. Many minutes dared to pass in such manner, and I was still fixated upon the empty and uniformly colored squares in front.
Try something at least!

Incidentally, I went ahead with the word “TRACE”, my strategy being to get the most commonly used letters for a hint at first. I tapped enter and watched in some horror as every letter flipped into utter black of its type. Not even a single alphabet was correct! And my heart skipped a beat.

I sure was stunned, but only for a second or two because I realized that even if the try wasn’t perfect, it seemed necessary to provide me with incredible hints moving forward. As a result, I decided upon using the next word as “WOODS” which contained none of the previously tried letters, yet it should give me some leeway over the final answer. Again the individual letters flipped one by one, revealing “WO” and “D” as still wretched black, while the remaining “O” stood green followed by “S” turning yellow towards the end.

Now we are talking!

Considerable levels of encouragement surged within as I began searching the towers of my memory through every five-letter word satisfying the given condition. I ultimately landed on “FROST”, it seemed like a pretty good and calculated guess. But if there is one thing consistent in WORDLE, is that it’s never what it seems like!

While “FR” and “T” still remained utter black, I got “OS” both in green this time.
Man, this is hard!
I gravely realized, trying to think of a new word that could help me inch closer to the ultimate answer.

What else contains “OS” in the middle?
I tried “GLOSS” next and it managed to give me the whole “LOS” in green. Surprisingly, the last “S” appeared in yellow.
There are two S’!

A new revelation rejuvenated life within me, but the fact that I was already above four tries in total induced severer nervousness. By the process of fairly simple elimination, the new-found “S” could only be correct at the first position. But I had yet to figure out the last letter.

“SLOS_” I mouthed.
What could come after S?
In an effort of classic brute force, I grew to put each of the un-blackened letters in the last position.

SLOSB

SLOSI

SLOSH

Wait…
Could it be SLOSH?
I pondered heavily.
Is that even a word?
I weighed in my all options, knowing that this being my fifth attempt, I might as well try it! Evidently, I entered “SLOSH” and watched impatiently as each and every letter slowly turned mighty green.

Yes!

***

While the above scenario seems like a typical experience of any WORDLE player on the surface, it may surprise you to know that it’s hiding an extremely powerful and possibly life-altering philosophy underneath!

Let me explain.

Our lives, ever-so changing, turbulent, eventful, and vivid, are all held sanely together only by our common aim to reach our self-defined goals. These goals or aspirations typically do not lie in the realm of ease, it is the reason why we so want and are particularly determined to reach them. But what seems even more difficult is the infinite dilemma of taking the very first step towards achieving our aim. We often become far too entangled within the web of making an absolute right or “perfect” first step. (I too,  am also guilty of this fact) And just like we tend to dwell upon our first try in WORDLE, we mirror that in life accordingly.

But let me break an interesting yet crucial fact to you.

Even after hundreds of researched articles on it, there is no “correct” first-try word existing for WORDLE, and correspondingly, there is no such absolute “right” step to take when we are taking our all-important initial step towards our main goal.

Yes, the first step is daunting, truly pivotal and it gravely matters in the long run, but not because we take the “perfect” one, but rather because we have the will to take it no matter what. And the beauty of WORDLE, which heavily mimics itself in life as well, is that even if you get all the black letters, you are always one step closer to the final goal, always learning crucial information along the way which will lead you to make the next best-try possible. Maybe you get a few yellow, or even green after it. You will learn something again from the experience and the next best-informed decision will be the result of it, all towards reaching your ultimate ambitions.

Maybe you are not receiving the green that you desperately want. But as in WORDLE, the game is still winnable until the sixth chance is made, and as in life, your goals are still achievable until your last breath is made.

By consistently learning from our previous tries and making the best possible next step, achieving our greatest of aspirations will become an inevitable fact, it will become our destiny. We will reach there no matter what, and no matter how. As long as we make the all-crucial first try, as long as we are constantly learning, there is nothing to stop us.

Could be that someone else reached a similar goal to yours in fewer tries. But that comparison, while incredibly easy to fall into, will always prove as an utterly pointless act. What we need is a tunnel-vision focus on our own growth, our own learning curve, and our own catalog of tries which will definitely lead us to reach our own sense of success.

As I would like to say:

When life gives you black letters, learn from it until you make em all green!

The key takeaways of The WORDLE Philosophy:

  1. Making the first try is more important than making the “perfect” try.
  2. Learn from your attempts. Evaluate what you did black and wrong, what you did green and right, and what you did yellow and could be better.
  3. Consistency is key. Keep learning and keep trying, making each next step the best step yet, all towards reaching your ultimate goal.
  4. And last of all, don’t stop until you make em all green!

When summarized like such, it does seem not too hard to inculcate, does it? That is because it isn’t!

The most astonishing fact is that countless of us who already take part in WORDLE daily, are already using this philosophy to win daily. We just need to mirror this in our actual lives! (Easier said than done, I know. But take the first try and see the difference)

Ultimately, what I want to ask all is this;

How many of my fellow readers are going to adopt The WORDLE Philosophy? What goals are you willing to achieve through this? What else can we learn from this simple word puzzle according to you?

Shoot away in the comments.

And at the end of my post, I would leave you all with a befitting quote from the great John C. Maxwell.

“The more you do, the more you fail. The more you fail, the more you learn. The more you learn, the better you get.”

I hope you stay safe and have a great life ahead 🙂

title: 25 Indicators That You Might Be A Computer Dumbass
content:
Yes, dumbass passwords that people use on their most trusted data and nude selfies. No wonder they get caught.

Don’t do this.

The link is above, but here’s a sample to show you that even you could break into these machines:

123456

123456789

12345

qwerty

password

12345678

111111

123123

1234567890

1234567

qwerty123

000000

1q2w3e

aa12345678

abc123

password1

author: {name=Coping with Anxiety and ADHD, email=false, last_name=Ameer!, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/copingwithanxietyandadhd, nice_name=copingwithanxietyandadhd, site_ID=2.00851749E8, login=copingwithanxietyandadhd, avatar_URL=https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/f4b942cec62ea74c93d6b505b5c45221?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, URL=http://copingwithanxietyandadhd.wordpress.com, first_name=Desire +, site_visible=true, ID=2.15034345E8, ip_address=false}
title: Episode 20 – Anxiety, ADHD and Social Isolation.
content:
Anxiety, ADHD, and social isolation.
Wow, we really know how to pick them, huh?

Well, more often than not, we make ADHD seem cool and people seem to want to have it because of how it’s been looking, so here’s one of the downsides.

Stick with me?
*holds a hand out in dramatic fashion.*

I have a problem. It’s not big as the other problems in the world, like global warming and the insanely high depression and suicide statistics, but it’ll do.

I am uncomfortable in social situations. If you’ve met me in person, you’ll see that unless you ply me with happy juice and/or involve me in the conversation yourself, I will stick to my phone.

It’s not like I can’t do it. I have amazing social skills. Most of you reading this, we’ve interacted. Could you tell that I was quaking in my office pants? No? Exactly.

Believe it or not, I have been feeling less present for a while now. Maybe like seven, or eight years.
What? I did say it was a while…
The worst has been in the last two years though.


I like to take up space, sure. But only in comfortable spaces. I am not a fan of parties. Or large gatherings. Seeing up to 30 people at once will send me into sensory overload, and I’ll end up stuck, looking at maybe 5-10 people. The rest will fade out, or not register in my head.

It gets worse. I used to be more comfortable on the internet because half of y’all will never see me, and I was okay with that. Screen to screen interaction. It was safe, I didn’t have to worry about nuances, body language, and tone. None of that.
When I took pictures, like the ones currently on my Instagram, I’d have no issues sending them to my friends, without them asking.
You’d open your phone and see 7 attachments from me, pictures/videos. Just because.

Now, I have withdrawn. I cannot handle texts or friendships, I don’t send anyone pictures of me unless explicitly asked because who in the name of all things wise and beautiful is stepping on anyone’s toes?
Not me.
I am invited to outings, and I don’t show up. My stims can be embarrassing. It can be exhausting.

I see people – like 10 at once and I don’t learn their names because I have no plans of knowing them. Because again, the topic. Social isolation.


What does that have to do with having ADHD and Anxiety?
The anxiety part is obvious. But whatever you have in mind? Intensify it. I don’t do anything small.

I am hyperactive, inattentive, and impulsive. I face social rejection, and I have terrible interpersonal relationships. I feel disconnected from family members and colleagues who don’t understand my challenges. And I feel too ashamed to ask for help.

There is a permanent sense of being alone with my challenges. Many ADHDers I know have lived in isolation as a way of protecting themselves from the misunderstandings of others and the familiar experience of rejection they have known growing up.

We’re “too intense” and “dramatic”. Honestly, people tell me all the time it’s exhausting. They say I’m exhausting. Like I chose to have such a stupid brain.
Not their fault either; there are just better ways to communicate it.


So to be less exhausting, I become small. Absent, a ghost.
Most people have never heard me nag about being depressed. It’s dumb stuff like school stress (lmao, August 1?) and being called all the time when I’m out.
Petty stuff, as discussed in the last episode.
Okay, maybe not so petty; homophobia, any queerphobia in 2022 is embarrassing. Fix up.
But you only hear me riled up about these things.

To be less in people’s faces, I limit my excitement rants. What I would have said in 29 texts, I say in 1. This one time-
No, we don’t talk about that time.😂

I don’t send pictures, I don’t text first, I say please and thank you and consistently ask if I’m being a bother with my broadcasts (for this exact blog you’re reading, it’s off a BC). I consistently ask partners, “is there anything I do that annoys you?”
And tell me that if you lived your life on your toes like me, you’d be excited about human interaction.
It’s okay, lie to me.

I’ll still be a social butterfly when you see me, of course. I speak well, and I read and update my vocabulary and brain often so I can keep up in conversation. But I get tired so fast. So easy.
So no, I don’t go out.
No, I don’t like most people in my space, my home, my room.
Most sha.
There are some people that if I was running away, they’d have ways to reach me, just them. Some people make me so comfortable, that I’d leave my home, my space just to see them. There are people I’d talk to every day and I’m okay with complimenting and sending random memes and shit. They are not intrusive. No pressure. Just me, how I come.

What? They’re comfy.

No offense to you people that aren’t. You’re just… pressure.
It’s possible you in particular aren’t, I also have text blindness.

Sha, ADHD makes me isolate because masking is hard and I’m terrible at doing it for more than an hour.

Isolation is a beautiful thing, and I love the freedom it has.

Every two to five weeks I get this urge to leave social media and just vanish from everything. I feel I do this because I get overwhelmed by everything. It’s ridiculous. Sadly, I can’t get my wish, my work is on social media plus how do Desire and I communicate on topics to write?

I am not very comfortable in social situations and I lack basic social and communications skills, it might come of as rude sometimes. For the 7th million time, you don’t have to touch me to get your point across to me and I don’t want to hug you. Stop stretching your hands out. Yes, I’m uncomfortable in situations where people touch me.

If I’m being honest, I’d rather be alone and listen to Lana del Rey’s Norman Fucking Rockwell for the 9 billionth time than go to a party. If I do go to the party, I know I’ll be psyched for five mins and would immediately want to be left alone. I would probably leave the people I came with, go somewhere and watch them have fun, cos, that shockingly feels better.
It’s this same reason why I struggle making new friends and talking to strangers because a part of me doesn’t want to be where I am, so don’t talk to me; I want to go home. 😭

On a more serious note, though, social situations give me anxiety and 70% of the time I’m focusing on the shiny object behind the person talking to me or I’ve probably just zoned out and I’m staring you dead in the eyes and I have no idea what you’re saying. I’ll sprinkle a few “oh” and “mad mad” in between but walahi, I don’t know what you are saying. Also, being bad with remembering people’s names makes me feel kinda like an arse cos my name is difficult to pronounce, so somebody remembering my name and pronouncing it right while I’m like “ your name is Tobi yeah?” doesn’t really do so much to help my brand.
Also, I find talking to people kinda exhausting in some situations; just shut up already, I don’t care, walahi I don’t.
This probably makes me seem like a bad person, cos I mean, I’m not that good a person, but still-
I-
I don’t know.
I feel like a part of me intentionally tries to sabotage friendships and stuff because I’d rather be alone and enjoy my company than go out and do something with a bunch of people I don’t know. Hence why I try to be in my space and push people out of it at any chance I get.
I still wouldn’t let you hug me sha, gimme a fist bump instead. Good!

Back to Desire I guess.

First of all, Ameer jokes too much. Let me move to hug you and you bring your fist. I’ll deck you.

But, I completely agree with everything he’s saying. That’s the anxiety aspect I assumed you knew earlier, and if you didn’t, well, now you do.

Do you think having energy is easy? It really isn’t.
How do I fix it?
There is nothing to fix.
It’s perfectly okay for me to not be in the mood for association sometimes. But I do appreciate the people who continually reach out and check in.

Plus I do that thing y’all call seeking attention, lmaoo. “I’ll be off/ unavailable for a while. If it’s urgent, call.” And I text people I was in conversation with. Tell them I’ll be away, offer a means to contact me.
That way, no one is unnecessarily worried or scared that I’m unaliving lol

Still, I communicate that I simply need a break.
I’m very dramatic, but I know there ARE spaces in which I’m important, fundamental. I’d never leave any of those people or spaces without adequately informing those affected.

Also, if that has been your concern the last six weeks, I’m fine. I just need some time away. That’s if you didn’t hear me the first seven times I said it. My social/ everything battery is really low and I’m going through things I don’t understand.

Enjoyed this episode? Or not? Leave us a like, comment and subscribe and share!
Have a good week ahead!

author: {name=stevewillette1, last_name=Willette, site_visible=true, site_ID=2.03659592E8, ID=2.18148054E8, avatar_URL=https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/1c05969cff46bea91a7d5c0f2c6d38d1?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/stevewillette1, email=false, nice_name=stevewillette1, login=stevewillette1, first_name=Stephen, URL=http://withwingsaseaglesblog.wordpress.com, ip_address=false}
title: Thankful & Grateful:  Lessons Learned Through a Pandemic.
content:
I like to solicit ideas for posts from others. It gives me insight as to what is on the minds of others around me. While I have a list of ideas written in a notebook; various topics I want to tackle at some point, I am intrigued what others are thinking and what they may want to see me write about.

The topic for this post is actually combining two ideas into one post, since I think we can gain valuable lessons from the last couple of years. The ideas come from two friends of mine; one being my former boss while I worked at the Code Blue Emergency Shelter in Saratoga Springs, New York. Those friends are Melanie Covell and Cheryl Ann Murphy-Parant.

As a society, culture, people, and individuals, we have had a lot thrown at us in just two years. We endured loss and separation due to Covid, we grew accustomed to seeing family members through video-chat instead of gathering together in homes. We wore masks in public. Many of us really learned the true meaning of loneliness. Anxiety and depression rose, drug use and alcohol consumption increased, and mental health declined for many.

But there were some things that came out of the last two years, and which if it wasn’t for everything we tackled together, I feel would still be lost. Things like eating dinner together as a family, cancelling elaborate family vacations and instead spending more intimate and quality time together doing smaller things, and in many households, rediscovering family game night. We shopped local and supported small-businesses. We had our children home full-time and had the opportunity to be more engaged in their education and learning. We took walks as a family, and discussed things that mattered to each other. We learned what it means to be thankful for the smallest of things. Remember the great toilet paper shortage of 2021? We came out of the last two years thankful. We focused on the simpler things in life, and realized that life can change rapidly and without notice.

Thankful. Prior to the events that have occurred in the last twenty-four months or so, thankful was a word normally confined to the month of November. You don’t typically see social media posts or hear people say that they’re thankful for little things, except for around Thanksgiving. Then everyone is thankful.

Since I started this post and shared how I worked at the Code Blue Emergency Shelter, I’m reminded of some of the guests I had the privilege of working for. Yes, I worked for them, because for the colder months here in upstate New York, the shelter was their home and I was a guest in their home. I’m reminded of so many individuals and how thankful they were for a hot meal on a frigid cold night. I think of their faces when they were given a warm jacket or new gloves. I’m reminded how many of them would step up and help clean because they were thankful they had a place to sleep that night; a warm cot and blanket rather than a cold park bench or the stairs in a parking garage.

What are you thankful for today? What have you learned over the last two years? I pray we never have to endure some of the sorrow and separation that we seem to be past now, again in our lifetime. But I also pray that we take the lessons we learned and pass them on to the next generation.

author: {login=earthyrealist101, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/earthyrealist101, site_ID=1.53274298E8, site_visible=true, nice_name=earthyrealist101, last_name=Realist, name=earthyrealist, ID=1.46531129E8, email=false, ip_address=false, URL=http://earthyrealist101.wordpress.com, first_name=Earthy, avatar_URL=https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/5b7ab64d3b9b7a940feb2b59e45e2395?s=96&d=identicon&r=G}
title: How To Make Time For Reading (Even When You Are Busy)
content:
I think that the most challenging part about reading a book for most is that they want to start a book and finish it immediately. If your schedule doesn’t permit for that, but you still want to read, here are two things that I do:

  1. Listen To Audiobooks – Though it’s not reading yourself, it’s another way to gather information provided in books. I listen to finance and personal development audio books often.
  2. Leave A Book Open On Your Counter Or Table – I really, really enjoy reading about aromatherapy, holistic living, and natural healing so I leave the book I’m currently reading open on the counter in my kitchen. When I’m cooking and at the end of the night I read a few pages.

Best Regards,

Aura Bea Carter

title: Kierkegaard in a Nutshell – Review
content:
Kierkegaard is regarded as the founder of existentialism.

In this book, a series of highlights from his major works, Kierkegaard asserts that if he were capable of grasping God objectively, he would not have faith. As he can’t do this, grasp God objectively, he requires his faith and if he wishes to retain this faith, he must hold fast to the objective uncertainty.

Faith is a matter of subjective decision, not objective knowledge.

Those who can really stand alone in the world, only taking counsel from conscience – they are the true heroes.

author: {URL=http://theantisimulation.wordpress.com, site_ID=1.76066097E8, ip_address=false, first_name=TAS, last_name=, site_visible=true, avatar_URL=https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4e9ccb7ae2a160f83222a31c351f73d4?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/theantisimulation, email=false, ID=1.84349816E8, name=The Anti-Simulation, login=theantisimulation, nice_name=theantisimulation}
title: The Real Reason to be Taking Cold Showers
content:
You have heard by now that a brisk wake-up in the cold will do wonders for your health. Even your personal self-worth. Or Entrepreneurship endeavours… 

Wim Hof et al. 

Self-improvement is masturbation.

One reason lies in the circuit trap created from the momentum that results in needing the next habit to fall in to. Once you master one – you should move on. If it doesn’t transfer then it is masturbatory momentum. 

The effects of cold showers are mental and physical – and they transfer. Unlike the kind of yoga that allows you some social scene with the model mums and mid-level earthy-trance chicks. You can sleep with your yoga teacher but most of the benefits of this self-improvement practice should transfer beyond the mat. 

The physical effects of yoga and cold showers are boring – But what if cold showers transferred spiritually?

This came together for me when reading The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People (now realising to be more fun to read than reading just the title) and after watching Julien Himself mention the practice: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pCZdJiGSk8g&t=5846s 

We set ourselves up to see the cold as being against I… 

I waddle to the shower. I turn it on. I brace. Linger. Do the pussy-step side-to-an-fro. 

After a wasteful amount of time I barrel through. 

Like any intense and tense moment in our lives this can be how we “handle situations”. We push ourselves through it. Force ourselves into it.

Like “traumatic episodes” there is a moment where someone will see themselves from the outside. This is an extreme example of the split in character that has resulted in social conditioning. Ever since you were old enough to see you as being different to another noun. 

Intense situation. We push ourselves out. 

Cold water. We brace.

Scary movie. We tense.

You can’t truly frighten an enlightened Zen monk.

}" data-image-title="0dcae2210a2bce0c24eb3a45e6e60760" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://theantisimulation.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0dcae2210a2bce0c24eb3a45e6e60760.jpg?w=240" data-large-file="https://theantisimulation.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0dcae2210a2bce0c24eb3a45e6e60760.jpg?w=564" src="https://theantisimulation.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0dcae2210a2bce0c24eb3a45e6e60760.jpg?w=564" alt="" class="wp-image-296" width="344" height="430" srcset="https://theantisimulation.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0dcae2210a2bce0c24eb3a45e6e60760.jpg?w=344 344w, https://theantisimulation.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0dcae2210a2bce0c24eb3a45e6e60760.jpg?w=120 120w, https://theantisimulation.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0dcae2210a2bce0c24eb3a45e6e60760.jpg?w=240 240w, https://theantisimulation.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0dcae2210a2bce0c24eb3a45e6e60760.jpg 564w" sizes="(max-width: 344px) 100vw, 344px" />

When we are triggered by social stimulus we must not push through by pushing ourselves into a different happy place. Often there is no way of not getting triggered. You can train yourself to be untriggered and not crumble into a fearful cowering hunched appearance upon seeing your smoke-show of an ex-. You could look at her new low-fi-porn interweb feed shots and practise what smooth punch lines you’re going to deliver that night at the evening event and when and how you’re going to deliver them and you can even chase vodka with more vodka and slap your face and get hyped and get swole… But what if she has a smoke-show friend? 

You haven’t trained for this… 

This is a problem of domain-specificity.

When you go to another place in “intense” situations you are pushing yourself out of reality. You are not whole. 

This is the Narrator in Fight Club. Tyler Durden is the “other place” that we go to. Where we want to be and Who we want to be.

One must realise that by tensing up. Barrelling into a situation. Psyching ourselves up. Throwing on that Eminem before we fight… We are training ourselves to be split in character and place. We are further conditioning ourselves to be tense and separate. Not One. Whole.

So what is the real reason to be taking cold showers? The real solution to social “anxiety”. It is not “dealing” with them but dissolving into them. Any kind of tenseness. Feel it. Then let it go.

Walk into the cold shower. Calmly. Slowly. Feeling it and the sensations of your body. It’s only cold if you say it is.

This is the opposite of “desensitisation”.

Get triggered by a stimulus. Deliberately. Then use that liberty of the present moment to go into it. You then have freedom to choose. Not be fragile to the situation – to each moment.

“What you are aware of, you are in control of; what you are not aware of is in control of you.” – De Mello. 

Seek to dissolve that inner split of consciousness and feeling. Feel it instead. When practising this you can dissolve the divide of who you are.

**

Is this all a metaphor? Obviously. 

But you should still be taking cold showers. 

When you wake up. It is not even a decision. There is only one tap. 

It is already decided. 

Flow into it.

}" data-image-title="thich-nhat-hanh-art-of-dying-well-nation-2.jpeg" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://theantisimulation.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/thich-nhat-hanh-art-of-dying-well-nation-2.jpeg.webp?w=202" data-large-file="https://theantisimulation.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/thich-nhat-hanh-art-of-dying-well-nation-2.jpeg.webp?w=690" src="https://theantisimulation.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/thich-nhat-hanh-art-of-dying-well-nation-2.jpeg.webp?w=690" alt="" class="wp-image-294" width="240" height="356" />

***

The Social Skills Manifesto: My STEP-BY-STEP Method

The Critical Importance Of Overcoming Past Trauma  |  Jordan Peterson

Antifragile. NNT. 

Awareness. De Mello
excerpt: When you go to another place in “intense” situations you are pushing yourself out of reality. You are not whole.

author: {site_visible=true, nice_name=edaley84, URL=http://daleydeliberation.wordpress.com, name=edaley84, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/edaley84, first_name=Elizabeth, last_name=Daley, site_ID=8.2042342E7, ip_address=false, login=edaley84, email=false, avatar_URL=https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/74c5f84dd9070b3af5034510b3e3051a?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, ID=7.8134169E7}
title: Access Wonder
content:
}" data-image-title="closeup photo of person s foot near mountain" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="

Photo by Samuel Theo Manat Silitonga on
rel=

>Pexels.com

" data-medium-file="https://daleydeliberation.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/pexels-photo-837745.jpeg?w=300" data-large-file="https://daleydeliberation.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/pexels-photo-837745.jpeg?w=1024" src="https://daleydeliberation.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/pexels-photo-837745.jpeg" alt="" class="wp-image-3524" />

We have the capacity and ability to live in awe at all times.  We are so blessed that we have the access to information, health, technology, communication, and expansion moreso than any age before us.  All of these feats are enough to impress people.  But when it comes to finding awe and humility, we have to look at the big picture.  We are ALIVE.  We are living, cognizant beings with the ability to transform this world.  We are breathing, performing complex chemical reactions in our bodies all day without a second’s thought.  We create life.  We create buildings and art and love.  We experience the elements and feel emotions.  Every second we are alive is a miracle.

I had a teacher who saw everything as a miracle and at first I didn’t understand.  Some of the things he would express joy at or compliment seemed so mundane to me.  I can see I was still tightly wrapped in my perfection phase and I misunderstood miracle.  I used to look at miracles as the perfect things that happened.  It took me a long time to understand that perfection has nothing to do with it.  The fact that we exist is a miracle.  The fact that we can do what we do with our lives, that we can feel what we do, is a miracle.  We have access to that at any time in any capacity.  We have to remember that in the moments it’s hard and the moments we are tired or feel like we are stuck.  We can change the story we tell ourselves and witness what this life really is: a miracle.

I feel a lot of shame and regret about all the time I spent in perfection.  I missed out on experiencing some really amazing things and I missed a lot of chances to feel that awe because I was too blind to see what was in front of me and to respect it.  I did it to myself for 37 years.  I never appreciated what I could do.  I never felt good enough for anything.  I never had confidence to listen to what I really needed let alone to go for it.  Maybe it’s age, maybe it’s realizing that all that time is gone that makes you look at how you’re spending the time you have.  Maybe it’s simply understanding that we have expectations no one can live up to and sometimes it’s enough to just BE.  Maybe it’s getting tired of the same game over and over again.  Whatever it is, looking at things differently changes the game.

In spite of any shame or regret, I mostly feel gratitude now—and I feel gratitude that I am able to feel grateful.  Once I had the realization of the trouble perfection caused, I felt guilty finding joy in anything else.  Kind of like waiting for the other shoe to drop.  I try to dip into that wonder as often as I can because it’s a great feeling.  For years it felt like it was so far under the surface, always miles to go in the race that I wouldn’t find it.  I dismissed things I should have been proud of when the joy and the magic was right there.  The beautiful thing is: it’s still there.  It never went anywhere.  So when we feel overwhelmed or annoyed or scared or angry, take a moment and reconnect with the wonder of it.  Be amazed that you have the capacity for such feelings and then be amazed that you can tune into your breath.  Be amazed at what you are and what you’ve done.  Then breathe out and be grateful you are here.  You only stop feeling when you’re dead, so find joy in being alive and find the awe in the miracle of this life.  Do not take it for granted.

author: {ID=3.5826914E7, last_name=Saffire, email=false, ip_address=false, avatar_URL=https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/1e29f4062e22663053b81d05c8e5dc70?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, nice_name=jenniferleigh1111, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/jenniferleigh1111, first_name=Jennifer, name=jenniferleigh1111, site_ID=2.02178156E8, login=jenniferleigh1111, URL=http://mentalpoise.com, site_visible=true}
title: A Faint Fuzzy Hum
content:
Depression isn’t always a dark negative mindset. Sometimes it’s more of a loss of interest in the world outside, and an excessive need to just be alone. You might not even feel so miserable; sometimes it feels like nothing more than a faint fuzzy hum lingering in the backdrop of your mind- lulling you inward and away from the racing world around you. Awake, aware, but not entirely there. Nothing may be apparently wrong, but nothing is quite right either. Another interesting conundrum of the elusively fucked up magnificent human mind. Perhaps it’s not depression at all. How we love to try to label everything.

Into the Void

Sometimes we try to dig into this obscure feeling, connecting the mental dots as we attempt to extract the roots from this dark spell. But, sometimes what we think is wrong is just a figment of our own imaginations. We are just so used to something being wrong that when there is nothing, we create something. When our minds are oddly calm, and there is nothing to be upset about, we stir the silence.

Although there is always something to be discovered deep within our thick skulls, sometimes there is more to be discovered within the void beyond those thoughts. This faint fuzzy hum is calling you, guiding you, teaching you. Listen and allow. There is no need to figure everything out. Sometimes we are just drawn away from the crowds so that we can take the time to truly connect and unveil the truth we have been seeking about ourselves. Tune into the faint fuzzy hum; go into the void and allow yourself to flow rather than fight. And when you start to feel good, don’t question it- run with it!

title: I Will Welcome Happiness
content:
}" data-image-title="img_0990" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://joycemccluskeyphotography.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/img_0990.jpg?w=225" data-large-file="https://joycemccluskeyphotography.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/img_0990.jpg?w=768" src="https://joycemccluskeyphotography.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/img_0990.jpg?w=768" alt="" class="wp-image-3422" srcset="https://joycemccluskeyphotography.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/img_0990.jpg?w=768 768w, https://joycemccluskeyphotography.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/img_0990.jpg?w=1536 1536w, https://joycemccluskeyphotography.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/img_0990.jpg?w=113 113w, https://joycemccluskeyphotography.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/img_0990.jpg?w=225 225w" sizes="(max-width: 768px) 100vw, 768px" />

I will welcome happiness for it enlarges my heart;

Yet I will endure sadness for it opens my soul.

I will acknowledge rewards for they are my due;

Yet I will welcome obstacles for they are my challenge.


— Og Mandino

    When August days are hot an’ dry,I won’t sit by an’ sigh or die,I’ll get my bottle (on […]

title: Conversations with an Angel – Tough Love
content:
Cleo Dunsmore Buchanan and Archangel Michael

I asked beloved Michael this morning, “Please beloved angel, will you tell me, is it better to be tough or supportive in the presence of weakness? I know many who are hamstrung by the tough love they have received in their lives. And I know others who never fly because they have been supported always and have no interest in risk. Please how do we know whether to be tough or to be supportive?“

Michael answered, “Of course this question is dear to your heart. You suffer from this injury. Who has hurt you child with their rough attitude and treatment recently? You know it is your own doing. Your interpretation of events creates the injury in yourself. You see this clearly now. So why ask the question? Do you seek to blame others?”

“Beloved angel, no. I am wondering how I should be behaving. When am I doing right and when am I being crippling when all I wish to do is love and support?“

“You are sensitive, and I ask you to consider something. What if your journey and their journey are intertwined? And each kindness and each frustration is a mutual experience? How great is your benefit when they have a breakthrough? How great is their benefit when you have a breakthrough? I see you struggle unnecessarily with this! 

Many times we believe our actions lead to certain outcomes. But it is not so. The collective is creating as well. You are not in control of the outcome. There is light all around you and all around them. Each of us is a conduit of our own vibration of light. When these come together there is brilliant synergy! There is wild growth and joy! 

I see you creating such in your life! I see you trusting and launching into these connections! I love this! It is joyous to behold! 

However you carry this malaise, that the outcome is your responsibility. This is not so. You are part of a creative collective which fashions an experience together. There is joy in this discovery. You are not the only one creating here. It is a group responsibility.”

“Beloved angel, I don’t understand. “

“Cleo, don’t you trust me to lead you well? This is great wisdom I offer you.”

“Beloved, I am just asking! I don’t see how this is an answer. It doesn’t address- what happens when we must choose between support and leaving them in the cold to find their way? How can we navigate this and find benefit instead of misunderstanding and harm? It seems to me impossible- everyone’s answer must be different.“

“What if it is? Your answer only you are aware of and you must constantly be aware of this and take care of it yourself. How do you get support when you need it? When do you strike out on your own and find your own strength? 

You yourself are very capable of finding this balance yourself. You ask for help when you need to. You seek reassurance when you need to. You are fully aware that this dynamic can be stifling if it is not fed and nurtured with independent successes. And you seek them out when you need to, correct? 

You must trust the universe. We are all here to complete this dynamic in unity. When we are part of the collective experience and everyone finds their strength, it benefits everyone tremendously. You are only opening these doors now. You have had all kinds of successes for yourself, alone. Now you are free to discover what it can mean to have this joy together, in ensemble. 

Cleo I think this question is brilliant. And as a mother you must feel the importance of it. Yet we are all individuals responsible for our path through life. We choose how to go and how to see every experience. We author every moment whether we know it or not.”

Thank you beloved angel!

Blessings!

author: {ID=2.21023377E8, name=Steven Ra Ga, email=false, first_name=Steven, avatar_URL=https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/2e879acae205d59f31cad3eb7690ef86?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, URL=http://stevesconfessionbusiness.wordpress.com, site_ID=2.06200775E8, ip_address=false, nice_name=stevenragadaily, login=stevenragadaily, last_name=Ga, site_visible=true, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/stevenragadaily}
title: Rejection
content:
Confessions of a Serial Interviewer by Steven Ra Ga

No body likes rejection. It hurts. But one thing to remember is not take it personally. It helps to brush it off and keep going.

Since the creation of job posting websites it’s become increasingly convenient for employers to pass on your application.

The typical indeed response goes like “Unfortunately we found the right candidate for this position”

I often wonder why they say that? Like it’s unfortunate they chose the right person for the position? Like how does that person feel? “Hey man you were unfortunately selected for this role.”

Or you get that personal email from HR explaining away why you weren’t picked which often feels like they are trying to not feel guilty.

Or sometimes you never hear back, the follow up to find out the chose someone else.

I personally can take rejection easily except when talking to women that shit never gets easy. I remember when I was single I would be terrified of asking a girl for their number in a cold call situation IRL. Online it was easy I developed a whole recipe for success. The perfect sales pitch.

What is rejection really though, I think it’s just another person telling you no, which dates back to when you were a kid and a parent would tell you no, that trauma, which may have been from a loving place, stuck with you as you aged. So when someone would reject your resume, idea or love advancement you could possibly project the feelings of your parents on to these people which is why it hurts so much when you get rejected.

For me, a letter of rejection from a job is meaningless, it holds no weight or volume to how I see myself, like junk mail that just needs to recycled or burnt.

Today I got rejected and felt like maybe I would share the response.

So a while back I decided to apply to some stores to sell my hobby art. I make creative jackets and furniture by up cycling them, that stated I have found the sales cycles to be long and difficult, utilizing other stores to sell my product in a department store model has been lightly successful… here is a response from one of the stores…

First of all, we apologize it took us so long to get back to you and thank you for your patience. We also want to thank you so much for your interest in selling your creations with [Blank], as well as the time it took to submit your application. We know your brand means the world to you and appreciate you sharing it with us, we are always blown away by the talent in our community!

We received hundreds of applicants in the last few months with interest to sell in one of our 4 shops and although we wish we could work with everyone, we just don’t have the space. With that said, a lot of our categories are currently full and your products fall among them so we unfortunately at this time are not able to accept your brand into our shops. This is not at all a reflection of your brand and we want to encourage you to continue your love for your creative journey. After all that’s what this is all about, (we think). Keep creating, keep growing and most of all love what you’re doing.

We thank you again, we wish you all the best and keep up the amazing work! We do encourage you to apply again in a few months as things are always changing. In the meantime we are now offering workshops and pop up space, you can find more details here

I it always feels like they are trying to cross all their T’s and dot their i’s when this kind of long winded response comes through. As though I am not busy enough, Now I have to read a novel why you said no rather than just simply saying no. And I know it’s because most people have difficulty saying the word no, so rather than saying just No there is always that long winding reason why it’s a no, so you don’t ask more questions…

Some times I feel like asking why just to get a response from the person who said no, to see if I can goat then into a hard no. Usually doesn’t work, sometimes I can befriend them in the process so it because like a forced awkward friendship, where you make plans to meet them for coffee then ghost them with a long winded response why meeting them isn’t high on your list of priorities between getting gas for your car and getting your hair cut.

Looks like I got another one…

Hello,

Unfortunately, [Blank Company] has decided not to move forward with your application at this time.

While we wish we had better news, continuing to search and apply for jobs will help you maintain your momentum. Best of Luck!

Okay, time to send out a few resumes…

Since the creation of job posting websites it’s become increasingly convenient for employers to pass on your application. The typical indeed […]

title: Loop of Psychology Culture
content:
Aren’t we sick of reading hype psychology quotes from the field of psychology. I mean, is this overly linear know thyself, find your inner reality business suffocating me only?

I feel like we are reading words over words about words? And never reach anywhere, and thats why infinite scrolldown feature is an absolute paralyser.

We need less of us but more seashells, carrot roots, cheese culture to look at, if we want to learn about ourselves really.

Daily intention for a selfie could be good for once, ok for twice but wtf afterwards. We are about to became a mirror facing a mirror, an endless reflection of nothingness.

Narcissus was lucky to die into his self-image but we are convinced that we can live in it. And that is one big ugly problem.

A Psychologist.

title: when i decided to let everything go…..
content:
There was that one moment that one time when I feel like no one is important to me anymore it’s okay if I let them go life is not going to change without them or even with them we always have ourself left , when no one is there ….
You know I always used to feel like dying and there is nothing wrong to talk about dying and suicides,anxiety these are the things you can talk openly and it’s normal …


I always feel like i am worthless and I can’t do anything no one is for me everyone leaves and forever isn’t forever…
And just look at me now…..
The day when i realised that every person isn’t same , everyone treats you differently evryone has their side and you too have your sides, it can be happy rude sad or anything…
And you can choose how to behave with people, it’s not nessasary to always being kind to everyone , it’s not nessasary to help everyone…..
It’s not nessasary to always say yes !
you can choose “NO” it’s just two letters if you don’t want to do that simply say no and even you don’t need to explain anyone that why you said no.. because who cares?
It’s okay to choose yourself over something else it’s okay to lose friends it’s okay to let anyone go…
Because it’s you not them you are going to stay with you till the end not them not everyone is you , you are rare don’t try to be someone else!  
And yeah it’s okay to have wrong choices, bad decision just make sure that you are going to make that bad decision good too..

title: Bomb Shelter [Book Review] and I Guess I Haven’t Learned That Yet [Book Review] #Essay #Memoir #MentalHealth
content:
May 13, 2022

Two Memoirs/Essays: Bomb Shelter and I Guess I Haven’t Learned That Yet #MentalHealthWeek

}" data-image-title="Bomb Shelter" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/bomb-shelter.jpg?w=194" data-large-file="https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/bomb-shelter.jpg?w=324" class="alignnone wp-image-19910" src="https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/bomb-shelter.jpg" alt="Bomb Shelter by Mary Laura Philpott (cover) Image: yellow text and a large turtle against a pinkish red background" width="201" height="310" srcset="https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/bomb-shelter.jpg?w=201&h=310 201w, https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/bomb-shelter.jpg?w=97&h=150 97w, https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/bomb-shelter.jpg?w=194&h=300 194w, https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/bomb-shelter.jpg 324w" sizes="(max-width: 201px) 100vw, 201px" />

Genre: Categories: Nonfiction, Memoir, Essay, Self-Help, Self-Reflection, Anxiety, Humor

My Summary:

Mary Laura Philpott is a self-proclaimed “optimistic worrier” or “anxious optimist.” This tendency intensified when she became a parent and believed that if she cared enough, she could keep her loved ones safe. One day, her teenage son experienced a seizure and she began to worry about what else could happen? How do you keep going and continue loving and caring when you don’t know what will happen next?

My Thoughts:

I imagine most of us have experienced that feeling of helplessness and anxiety and worry over the ones for whom we are responsible. I know I have. In fact, if you are a fan of the NBC drama This is Us, a scene in one episode touched me profoundly. Randall is at the cabin working and has visions/imaginary conversations with Jack about his anger toward Rebecca for keeping the truth about his bio father from him…..Jack encourages Randall to see the situation from Rebecca’s perspective. Through the window, Randall glimpses a frantic Rebecca closing and locking all the windows and doors in an effort to keep her family safe. So moving. A perfect picture of how I felt as a parent of a growing family…..so many worries and dangers to keep at bay.

“It’s true. There will always be threats lurking under the water where we play, danger hiding in the attic and rolling down the street on heavy wheels, unexpected explosions in our brains and our hearts and the sky. There will always be bombs, and we will never be able to save everyone we care about. To know that and to try anyway is to be fully alive. The closest thing to shelter we can offer anyone is LOVE, as deep and wide and as in as many forms as we can give it.“

Philpott shares honestly how her anxiety was triggered as a parent. Isn’t it helpful knowing others have felt the same? Experienced the same? I think the book is relatable for parents or anyone who experiences episodes of anxiety or worry.

Philpott’s writing style and reflections are conversational, engaging, mostly light-hearted, and sprinkled with humor.

Recommended for anyone who experiences anxiety and/or worries.

Content Considerations: epilepsy, anxiety

My Rating: 4 Stars.

}" data-image-title="I Guess I Haven’t Learned That Yet" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/i-guess-i-havent-learned-that-yet.jpg?w=143" data-large-file="https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/i-guess-i-havent-learned-that-yet.jpg?w=143" class="alignnone wp-image-19906" src="https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/i-guess-i-havent-learned-that-yet.jpg" alt="I Guess I Haven't Learned That Yet by Shauna Niequist (cover) Image: colorful text against a white background" width="200" height="305" />

Genre/Categories: Nonfiction, Memoir, Essays, Self-Help, Self-Reflection, Grief, Faith, New Beginnings

My Summary:

Shauna Niequist’s carefully and thoughtfully cultivated life as she knows it falls apart after her fortieth birthday. What do you do when your entire life has revolved around your father’s church and your life-long, close-knit community of family and friends all collapse when your father is accused of inappropriate behaviors at his mega-church and resigns (not detailed). What happens when the happy and secure life in the mid-west you’ve dreamed of and carefully built falls apart around you? Well….you might move to Manhattan and rethink everything.

My Thoughts:

I suspect most of us can relate to a life that isn’t at all what we expected or dreamed about. We may face unexpected financial problems, toxic relationships, family disappointments, broken friendships, health concerns, etc. What then? What happens when all you want to do is quit? Does everything fall apart or can we learn to live in a new way, make adjustments, gain new perspectives, forgive, show compassion, navigate heartbreak and grief, and accept unknowns? Can we rebuild, refocus, and retool?

“…Life is…interconnected and multifaceted. We carry around our whole selves…our past and our parents, our loves and our limitations our dreams and our grocery lists, and our wounds.”

I need to note:

  • Not all of us have the option of relocating and starting a new life, have access to vacation homes, or can take a year off work to pull ourselves together. Nevertheless, she has some good things to share!
  • Some readers are frustrated that Niequest never shares the nature of the issue with her father and the church that motivated her memoir. Her intentional vagueness is out of respect for her father’s privacy….and really the issue is her dad’s to write about….she’s sharing how her life changed and how she adjusted to those changes as a result of what happened. I had followed the news story when it came out, so her vagueness didn’t bother me. He’s easy to google if you’re interested (Bill Hybels).

Recommended for anyone who is facing a life change.

My Rating:  4 Stars

}" data-image-title="Shauna Niequist" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/shauna-niequist.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/shauna-niequist.jpg?w=500" class="wp-image-20070 alignleft" src="https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/shauna-niequist.jpg" alt="Author Shauna Niequist" width="151" height="151" srcset="https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/shauna-niequist.jpg?w=151&h=151 151w, https://readingladiesblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/shauna-niequist.jpg?w=302&h=302 302w" sizes="(max-width: 151px) 100vw, 151px" />Shauna Niequist is the author of Cold Tangerines, Bittersweet, Bread & Wine, Savor, and Present Over Perfect.

She is married to Aaron, and they live in Manhattan with their sons, Henry & Mac.

Shauna is a bookworm, a beach bum, and a passionate gatherer of people, especially around the table.

QOTD:

Do you love memoirs? Are these titles on your TBR or have you read one or both?

Happy Reading Book Buddies!

“Ah, how good it is to be among people who are reading.”
~Rainer Maria Rilke

“I love the world of words, where life and literature connect.”
~Denise J Hughes

“Reading good books ruins you for enjoying bad ones.”
~Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society

“I read because books are a form of transportation, of teaching, and of connection! Books take us to places we’ve never been, they teach us about our world, and they help us to understand human experience.”
~Madeleine Riley, Top Shelf Text

Let’s Get Social!

Thank you for visiting and reading today! I’d be honored and thrilled if you choose to enjoy and follow along (see subscribe or follow option), promote, and/or share my blog. Every share helps us grow.

author: {ID=1.25329617E8, login=felixfelicitated, nice_name=felixfelicitated, ip_address=false, URL=http://felixfelicitatedblog.wordpress.com, last_name=Roychowdhury, first_name=Anwesha, name=Esha, email=false, site_visible=true, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/felixfelicitated, site_ID=1.33017436E8, avatar_URL=https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/673dc65f451d31c4d24e7de04eb66e7a?s=96&d=identicon&r=G}
title: [ARC] Book Review #22: ‘Love Your Life Workbook: Over 120 exercises to design a life you love’
content:
Note: The author, Ayesha Ratnayake, kindly sent me a digital version of her book in exchange for my honest review. A huge thank you to the author for letting me be a part of it.

Name: Love Your Life Workbook: Over 120 exercises to design a life you love

Author: Ayesha Ratnayake

Genre/s: Self-help

Today, I am going to review something completely different from the usual books. It is a workbook, named Love Your Life Workbook: Over 120 exercises to design a life you love by Ayesha Ratnayake. Last year, Ayesha reached out to me about her book Cheat Sheets for Life: Over 750 hacks for health, happiness and success. It was a great non-fiction book, with bite-size pieces of practical advice on how to carve out your best life as possible (you can read my review here).

The Love Your Life Workbook has everything you need to reflect on your time and life and get the best out of it. There are numerous exercises to do. The author, Ayesha Ratnayake, has laid down all the groundwork and all you have to do is take some time and fill them honestly. It is a great way to reflect on yourself and seek self-improvement.

I was also happy with the exercises. Several of them are quite innovative, such as writing your eulogy. I also liked worksheets exploring the concept of Ikigai, figuring out your dream job, habit ideas and habit trackers.

Final Thoughts

The book is a clear idea of short and effective ideas woven together to produce positive outcomes. It is practical and can be done more than once. I suggest doing so annually to keep track of your life and improve yourself in the long run!

My Rating

⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

Rating: 5 out of 5.

You can read my other book reviews here.
