title: Love Me, Me Loves
content:
What did they use to say? Self-love isn’t? It’s good for you and the people around you. It’s been a stressful week. I have felt so low and would need to focus my energy on a positive note.

I don’t know where this negative feeling is coming from. What I do know is I need to acknowledge that this feeling is valid.

Yesterday, I was feeling so restless and sad. So I went to the nearest hair salon. I pampered myself. New hair color and a little bit of hair treatment. The feeling was superb. I felt happy when I looked at my new me in the mirror. Me, myself, and I are smiling back at me! It felt like, they were cheering and rooting for me.

Today, I woke up inspired. I feel like I can take on anything. I asked my husband to join me in a quick stroll at the mall. You can call it a date if you want. Simple talks. Just the two of us. Funny that our conversation is also growing old. I loved that we were able to spend some alone time together. Before we go home, I bought myself a pair of sandals. By the way, that new pair of sandals is not in my plan. Can I add it to “self-love ” too? Lol!

My weekend is just the same. Nothing special. But I made sure that it is well spent.

Self-love means that you accept yourself fully, and treat yourself with kindness and respect, and having appreciation for oneself.

The Random Vibes

title: Deborah Samuel: There’ll be reprisal, civil war if you fail to act now – HURIWA to Buhari, Tambuwal
content:
Human Rights Writers Association of Nigeria, HURIWA, has condemned the conspiratory silence for over 24 hours of President Muhammadu Buhari over the brutal hacking to death of a 200 level Christian student of the Sokoto College of Education, Miss Deborah Samuel Yakubu, by Islamic extremists in the school over alleged blasphemy.

HURIWA warned that reprisals may become inevitable if the case of murder of Deborah in Sokoto is swept under the carpets like similar cases of murders of Christians over alleged blasphemy by Islamists in Kubwa, Abuja, and twice in Kano State.

The rights group told Sokoto State Governor, Alhaji Aminu Tambuwal and the hierarchy of the ill-fated school that the blood of the innocent Christian girl murdered in broad daylight is on their heads and generations unborn won’t forgive them for their seemingly ominous inaction.

HURIWA said it is urging that the strongest deterrent action provided by law is applied against the killers of Deborah who are even captured on video recordings or else the Federal Government has unwittingly authorised that reprisals should occur and the violence will do Nigeria no good because religious violence could lead to a civil war.

“HURIWA is very much aware, that President Muhammadu Buhari did not mince words to condemn Indigenous Peoples of Biafra(IPOB) even without any scientific evidence linking them remotely or otherwise to the gruesome and despicable beheading of the soldiers’ couple massacred by unknown gunmen reportedly on their way to a traditional wedding in the South East of Nigeria. President Muhammadu Buhari even gave an order that the killers be hunted down and dealt with decisively by military forces.

“President Muhammadu Buhari did this aforementioned hurriedly but generally hasty reaction because the perceived or suspected killers are Igbos, an ethnicity that his administration has treated with the short end of the stick for not voting for him in 2015 and 2019.

“But since over 28 hours that a Christian student of the Sokoto College of Education, Deborah Samuel Yakubu, was lynched by Islamic students for alleged blasphemy, President Muhammadu Buhari has maintained conspiratorial silence as if the innocent blood that was shed by the extremists is not that of a human being.

“This same hypocrisy of conspiratorial silence was noticed with the Sokoto State governor who stayed away from taking action but secretly sent his commissioner for higher education to speak on the murder.

“We in HURIWA want to let him Tambuwal and Buhari know that so long as there is no justice for this murdered Martyr Miss Deborah Yakubu, her innocent blood is on their heads”.

HURIWA condemned the management of Shehu Shagari College of Education in Sokoto for standing by and for doing next to nothing whilst the riotous Islamic extremists within the students body descended on their fellow student and killed her like a chicken but only made timid announcement of the so-called indefinite closure of the institution after a female student was reportedly killed for alleged blasphemy.

HURIWA said it is preposterous that the late student, believed to be a Christian, was stoned to death and burnt just because she was reportedly said to have attributed her academic excellence to Jesus and rankled by her response, she was asked to withdraw the statement — to which she refused even as her refusal to apologise made the mob attack her and then set her body ablaze.

The Rights group wondered when Sokoto has become an Islamic State when section 10 of the Constitution recognises Nigeria as a SECULAR STATE whereby no RELIGION IS A STATE RELIGION.”

HURIWA, in a statement by Comrade Emmanuel Onwubiko its National Coordinator, however blamed the management for not adequately providing her security by failing to call for police and military beef up but simply sacrificed the Christian student at the altar of religious extremism and hypocrisy.

HURIWA said religious pluralism and freedoms have suffered organised criminal attacks since President Muhammadu Buhari who before he won election in 2015 supported the introduction of full shariah law in Northern Nigeria, became President but nobody who killed Christian has ever been known to have been punished in accordance with the law of Nigeria thus creating the impression that the laws of Nigeria are not meant to be effective in the core Moslem North.

title: Deborah Samuel: Enough is enough – CAN directs all churches to hold nationwide protest
content:
The Christian Association of Nigeria, CAN, has directed all churches across the country and Christian stakeholders to embark on a peaceful nationwide protest over the lynching of Deborah Samuel, a 200-level student of Shehu Shagari College of Education, Sokoto State.

DAILY POST reports that there have been tension in many parts of the country following the gruesome murder of the Christian student, who was burnt alive over alleged insult on Prophet Muhammed.

Recall that pandemonium broke out in some parts of Sokoto State on Saturday following protest by Muslim men who violently protested the arrest of alleged killers of Deborah.

The protesters, who were demanding for the immediate release of the suspects, destroyed some churches, shops and other properties belonging to Christians.

A circular released on Saturday night by CAN’s General Secretary, Joseph Daramola, said the protest would be organized by churches across the country to demand justice for the deceased.

“The protest will take place on 22 May, 2022 in the afternoon by 3pm in every secretariat of the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN) nationwide and not on the streets in order to avoid further loss of lives.

“We urge those who could afford it to make use of the traditional media and social media to give it wide coverage in order to sensitise the whole world. We also call on Nigerian Christians in the diaspora to join us using our embassies all over the world.

“The occasion can also be used to pray for Deborah’s family and friends, peace for the country, victory for the Church and godly political leaders in the coming general election. Thanks, and God bless you all,” the Church organization said.

The circular directed Christians to hold placards with some succinct messages like “WE DEMAND JUSTICE FOR DEBORAH;
CHRISTIANS ARE NOT SECOND CLASS CITIZENS; NO MORE KILLING IN GOD’S NAME; ENOUGH IS ENOUGH; POLICE, STOP UNPROVOKED KILLINGS IN NIGERIA.”

title: Discipleship Series; 15 May, 2022
content:
Discipleship Series; 15 May, 2022 

DECLARATION: I am not worried, because I have and enjoy God’s riches and resources. Amen.

Matthew 6:27 – 30, Which of you by worrying can add one cubit to his stature? So why do you worry about clothing? Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow: they neither toil nor spin: and yet I say to you that even Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of these. Now if God so clothes the grass of the field, which today is, and tomorrow is thrown into the oven, will He not much more clothe you, O you of little faith?

The English dictionary explains ‘worry’ as, something or someone that disturb the peace of mind of, to be afflicted with mental agitation or distress, and something or someone that causes anxiety; a source of unhappiness. And has the following synonyms; concerned, anxious, troubled, or uneasy.

Matthew 6:31, Therefore do not worry, saying, “What shall we eat?” or “What shall we drink?” or ‘What shall we wear?

That emotion ‘worry’ is one of the major signs and indicators to the fact that we have crossed the line and boundary of custodian to ownership, where and when people have over-stretched themselves over and beyond their God-given roles and responsibilities.

Matthew 6:32, For after all these things the Gentiles seek. For your heavenly Father knows that you need all these things.

I am of the belief and opinion that there could be at least two (2), perhaps three (3) reasons why people worry and fret about their needs and their lives;

  1. People do not know how much resources God has at His disposal,
  2. People do not know how much God loves them, and
  3. People doubt God’s willingness and desire to help, assist or/and bless them.

PRAYER: Oh God! Help me see, know and understand You and Your love for me, in the name of Jesus Christ.

You can subscribe to this devotional via Telegram channel at, https://t.me/discipleship_series, or by following my blog, https://delateur.wordpress.com/category/religion/

author: {name=marklevigne, avatar_URL=https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/9efd27b189f50cf3e40f0309e8ac7b2a?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, site_visible=true, ID=9084232.0, ip_address=false, site_ID=8771682.0, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/marklevigne, nice_name=marklevigne, last_name=Levigne, first_name=Mark, email=false, URL=http://facebook.com/dreamsandvisionsband, login=marklevigne}
title: Pay It Forward
content:
Beth and I were eating at Olive Garden one evening. It was just a few hours of “us time” that we took advantage of (for once….) and enjoyed ourselves. Beth happened to notice an elderly gentlemen who was sitting behind me/over my right shoulder, out of line of sight (without being obvious and twisting around asking “Where!? Where!?…”) eating dinner by himself.

A few years back we were heading out to see family, stopping at a Denny’s along the way to grab dinner ahead of time. It was no special occasion, we had all four children with us at the time, and with nothing else in the area, settled on Denny’s that night. We sat down, ordered and began to enjoy our meal and visiting together. When time came for the check we were informed that someone else had paid our bill that evening. The wait staff referred to a gentlemen who noticed our family and asked for our bill to be added to his. We were told that even the tip was covered that night. We looked around but but discovered that he had already paid his/our bill and had left the restaurant. We could not even thank him for his unexpected act of generosity. Our could we?

As Beth and I sat and visited, discussed the day, errands to do while we were out and about we could help but think about the elderly gentlemen sitting by himself just a few steps away. Who was he? Was he single, married, a widower? Why was he dining alone this evening? Was he traveling, on business, out running errands as we were? Beth smiled, leaned in to me, and said, “Lets cover his bill tonight? Do you remember that time at Denny’s when…..” Yes, I quickly agreed. Lets do that. We can never repay the man who ‘made our evening’ and treated us six to dinner that night (no small total, even at Denny’s let me tell you…) but we can ‘pay it forward’. So we did.

When our wait person returned to refill drinks I quietly asked him if the gentlemen over my shoulder had already paid his bill. We were pleased to hear that he had not and asked our wait person to please give us his bill as we would like to cover his meal. He smiled and said he would take care of that for use.

}" data-image-title="image" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://marklevigne.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/image.png?w=300" data-large-file="https://marklevigne.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/image.png?w=550" src="https://marklevigne.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/image.png?w=550" alt="" class="wp-image-724" width="419" height="268" srcset="https://marklevigne.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/image.png?w=419 419w, https://marklevigne.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/image.png?w=150 150w, https://marklevigne.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/image.png?w=300 300w, https://marklevigne.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/image.png 550w" sizes="(max-width: 419px) 100vw, 419px" />

As we continued to enjoy our meal and time together, Beth acknowledged that the gentlemen was leaving and not only had his leftovers and ‘2nd meal to go’ packed up, but was walking out with a big smile on his face. We knew how he felt all too well. “Someone noticed me and covered my bill tonight” Where was he going? Who was he going to see? We never knew, but we knew we made a small difference in his life that evening. Someone covered his meal. Someone paid his debt. Someone sent him on his way home (?) with no cost.

Someone covered our bill a long, long time ago. They paid a debt that we could never, in a 1,000 lifetimes, ever repay. We can not even begin to think about how we could do that. And we really shouldn’t bother. What we should be doing is looking for more opportunities to “pay it forward”. To show compassion on those around us who need to know that someone noticed them. Someone saw their need, however small, and decided to do something about it. Pay it forward; its a great feeling.

For “whatsoever you do to the least of your brothers and sisters, you do unto me,” says the Lord Jesus.

Mark Levigne lives with his wife Beth and three wonderful kids Katie, Aaron and Stephen, in Medina, Ohio.  By trade he is a singer, musician, song writer, worship leader, and actor, and is a proud Air Force dad of Matt who is stationed overseas.  To pay the bills he is an IT guy at a really nice company in Akron.

If you liked what I had to say, please LIKE it and feel free to leave a reply.  Thank you!

title: #2321 Exploring Autumn vibes
content:
It takes concerted effort to do things that feed your soul. Often if we just go with the flow, although there’s a certain relaxing element to it, we can lose sight of our days, our weeks, and time can easily slip away.

I’ve been wanting to go to the Dandenong Ranges for ages now. I’m always reminded of it in Autumn, one of the most beautiful times of the year… especially for a place with so many trees and variety of them.

We scheduled it in, and it finally happened today. We spent a lovely day in the hills, crunching leaves under our feet, walking into boutique shops, and eating the afternoon away.

title: Netherlands: The Hague/Den Haag (part 1)
content:
With our son and his family newly settled in The Netherlands, our first stop on our first journey in two years had to be their adopted city of The Hague (Den Haag in Dutch).

After an uneventful KLM flight from Vancouver to Amsterdam, we purchased our train card (see TripBits) and then followed signs (and our remote guide in the form of our son, Kyle, and his NS app) to catch a train to Den Haag Centraal, about 30 minutes away. On arrival, our nine-year-old grandson, Alex, sprinting toward us at top speed and greeting us with great big hugs was a boost to our jet-lagged spirits. Alex was our guide for the final leg of our journey, a short tram ride to his new neighbourhood (while his parents, who were also there to greet us, returned home on their bicycles). When we were settled in, Kyle and Alex took us for a short walk to see a little of their pretty neighbourhood and its green spaces.

}" data-image-title="20220503_171318" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220503_171318.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220503_171318.jpg?w=1024" src="https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220503_171318.jpg?w=736" alt="" class="wp-image-15287" srcset="https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220503_171318.jpg?w=736 736w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220503_171318.jpg?w=150 150w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220503_171318.jpg?w=300 300w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220503_171318.jpg?w=768 768w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220503_171318.jpg?w=1024 1024w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220503_171318.jpg 1200w" sizes="(max-width: 736px) 100vw, 736px" />

With Alex on the last few days of his spring school holiday, we were able to spend the day with him while his parents worked and ran errands. It was so cool to have him lead us around his neighbourhood, showing us his school, the shopping street, and his favourite parks with such joy and confidence.

May 4 is Remembrance Day in the Netherlands (we hadn’t realized), where civilians and soldiers who have died since the outbreak of World War II are honoured with half-mast flags, ceremonies and two minutes of silence. It is always followed by Liberation Day on May 5, which celebrates when the Netherlands was liberated from German occupation and flags are raised again. Oddly, Liberation Day is only an official holiday every five years (next in 2025), but Kyle had the day off so we were all free to head into town for our first glimpse of the city.

}" data-image-title="20220505_121153" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220505_121153.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220505_121153.jpg?w=1024" data-id="15288" src="https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220505_121153.jpg?w=736" alt="" class="wp-image-15288" srcset="https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220505_121153.jpg?w=736 736w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220505_121153.jpg?w=150 150w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220505_121153.jpg?w=300 300w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220505_121153.jpg?w=768 768w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220505_121153.jpg?w=1024 1024w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220505_121153.jpg 1200w" sizes="(max-width: 736px) 100vw, 736px" />

}" data-image-title="20220508_113843" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220508_113843.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220508_113843.jpg?w=1024" src="https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220508_113843.jpg?w=736" alt="" class="wp-image-15299" srcset="https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220508_113843.jpg?w=736 736w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220508_113843.jpg?w=150 150w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220508_113843.jpg?w=300 300w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220508_113843.jpg?w=768 768w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220508_113843.jpg?w=1024 1024w, https://lifephasenext.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/20220508_113843.jpg 1200w" sizes="(max-width: 736px) 100vw, 736px" />

This first visit to Den Haag was short and sweet–time to reconnect with family and to get a feel for their new home city. We’ll be spending several weeks in the area in July, giving us lots of time to explore and experience more.

TripBits

  • Train card: At the NS (Nederlandse Spoorwegen, the Netherlands main railway company) counter (follow the signs for trains and locate the counter in the large open hall) we purchased our OV-chipkaart to make travel throughout the Netherlands simpler (and, hopefully, a little cheaper). At the cost of €7.50 ($10.50CAD) per card for five years, and with a plan to spend at least a month in the Netherlands on this trip, it seemed like a worthwhile investment to allow tap-on/tap-off travel with no need to purchase tickets.
  • Train: From Schiphol Airport to Den Haag Centraal, €9.30 ($13 CAD).
  • Bicycles: Cycling is a way of life in Amsterdam, and is well-supported by the transportation infrastructure of bikeways, trains, trams, and buses. Bicycles even form part of the NS train system, and can be picked up at a station for the final ride to work or home, kept for the day or night, and returned to the station within 24 hours. Our anonymous OV-chipkaart train cards (no photo, no ID required) don’t allow access to these bikes, but there were other short-term bike options. We chose HTM fiets, part of the tram system, and were able to locate bikes not far from home. We paid €5 ($7CAD) per bike for a 24-hour period.

title: Fiddle-dee.
content:
The best music comes from the heart, not sheet music. 

Thus says the noir detective fiction story writer, Montgomery Stratton.  Stratton has a point – music is best when the musician plays from the heart and the deepest parts of the soul.  Otherwise, all that emanates is a cacophony of musical notes that anyone can bang out.

But when the heart and soul speak . . .

©2022 Colcannon Metropolis, excerpt from “Points Well Taken”

title: The Arizona Desert
content:
A quick and great trip out west to Tucson which was amazing. We love Tucson and the resort we stay at, the landscape, the food, the sun, and the heat. Here is a short recap of our trip which started out with our flights being canceled out of O’Hare and we were 1 hour from leaving to drive up to the airport. Talk about a frustrating experience that seems more and more common now. We got a full refund on our flight (not a voucher, I would not take a voucher) and we were able to book flights out of Indianapolis that left an hour earlier and returned about 12 hours later than what we had previously booked. The flights cost us more, but it worked.

We rushed to Indianapolis caught the flight and flew into Phoenix and then drove about 1.5 hours to Tucson. Tucson is a great city! Surrounded on two sides by the Saguaro National Park, the area is filled with bike trails, hiking, parks, great restaurants, and lots of outdoor activities. The saguaro cactus (which is the large, tall, traditional-looking cactuses) line the roads, landscape, parks, and mountains. The sunsets are amazing, and the sky is always blue.

The Wyndham Grand Resort is a wonderful place to stay and provides a lot of great views of the mountains. It consists of suites, multiple pools, a tennis club, horseback riding, a great workout facility, a restaurant, live music at night, trails, and many other amenities.

We are hoping to take the kids in the future. The heat will challenge us all (76 degrees by 6 am in the morning and 98 by 10 am) but such a beautiful yet harsh landscape filled with life. The kids have not seen a saguaro cactus in person (they have in botanical gardens) but to see thousands of them is awesome. To look at them up close and see how old they are, and to understand their strength and resilience to the dry, hot weather is pretty amazing.

Upon return, it happened to jump from maybe 1 week of spring straight to summer.  Welcome to Indiana… Excited to be home but we can’t wait to go back!

title: Teenagers, Troubles, and Irish Accents
content:
}" data-image-title="derry-girls-1680×1120-1" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://rebekahthebacon.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/derry-girls-1680x1120-1.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://rebekahthebacon.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/derry-girls-1680x1120-1.jpg?w=1024" class="wp-block-cover__image-background wp-image-1031" alt="" src="https://rebekahthebacon.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/derry-girls-1680x1120-1.jpg" data-object-fit="cover" />

Derry Girls is the best and I won’t take no for an answer

Derry Girls has returned to our screens with their third and final series, once again throwing us into the lives of Erin, Orla, Clare, Michelle, and James – five girls (well, one’s a boy) from Derry (again, the bloke is from London) making their way through the turmoil of being a teenager in the 90s. Set against the backdrop of Ireland slowly working towards peace between Catholics and Protestants, North and South, the five find themselves time and time again in ridiculous situations that are all too relatable. 

I recently read an article about the show which claimed what made it so captivating was that the stakes are so low. No matter what the girls (and James) do, it has no real significance or impact on the world. I know this was meant in a complementary way, but I can’t help feeling that this is entirely backwards and incredibly belittling. 

From my viewing, every episode has set the stakes higher and higher tackling massive topics such as LGBTQ+ attitudes in the 90s, gender stereotypes, war and politics, religion, family relationships, friendships, love, identity, wealth, and how old is too old for ‘Rock the Boat’. These aren’t small subplots, briefly mentioned before returning to a comedic teenage coming of age show, but right at the heart of each episode. These are topics that still hold huge significance now, possibly not often associated with teenage girls for fear of minimising their complexity. If these don’t set the stakes high, I can’t imagine what will except for transferring these themes into a programme with less … teenage girls. 

I think this is why the comment comes across as belittling – because we know these themes are important as we are constantly discussing them and seeing them in our arts, work, and culture. Yet they seem to be mutually exclusive to things that teenagers deem important. Lisa McGee, the director, shows this is not the case at all by presenting how these themes impact the Derry girls throughout every aspect of their lives. The themes are important to the girls too – they don’t laugh them off but take them seriously, over-thinking and analysing them from every angle. We need to stop underestimating teenagers and their priorities, labelling them as ‘low stakes’, because in many ways teenagers share ‘adult’ priorities but respond to them in more exaggerated and honest ways.

The individual characters are also amazing and so true to what teenagers are like. I feel like I knew all five of the girls during secondary school and even the adults have personalities that I see in people around me. They aren’t caricatures or overly exaggerated, which adds to the honesty and authenticity of the show. With friends, I have easily assigned different roles to people we know, recognising their inner Jenny Joyce or Aunt Sarah ditziness. The humour is funny because I feel like I’ve experienced those conversations myself, whether as one of the participants in it or as an onlooker.

author: {name=CrystalSmithLove, site_visible=true, avatar_URL=https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/50aaef577010f65bad01ad02fe16972b?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, first_name=Crystal, URL=http://crystalsmithlove.com, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/crystalsmithlove, email=false, login=crystalsmithlove, nice_name=crystalsmithlove, site_ID=2.01760181E8, last_name=Smith, ID=2.16039231E8, ip_address=false}
title: Our Family Reading Day
content:
“Children are made readers on the laps of their parents.” – Emilie Buchwald

“To learn to read is to light a fire; every syllable that is spelled out is a spark.” – Victor Hugo

“Once you learn to read, you will be forever free.” – Frederick Douglas

“The more that you read, the more things you will know. The more that you learn, the more places you’ll go.” – Dr. Seuss

“Reading is a discount ticket to everywhere.” – Mary Schmich

Today was a day I had longed for since my youngest child was born, our first family independent family reading day. I have joyful memories of cozying up with a good book and reading for hours. My husband is also an avid reader, but Audible has become our friend since life has become busier with three children, a family business, and full-time jobs. I have still longed for the day that our entire family could enjoy a good book independently. Well, today was that day, and I foresee many more in our future.

We have to give Josiah and Serenity credit for sparking a desire in our family to read hardback books again. Josiah is our 3rd grader, and he has been working hard for the last two years to improve his reading skills. He has attended reading camps and participated in tutoring and intervention. Josiah has been striving to discover his love for reading. Intriguingly, he has found the motivation to improve his reading by reading the Bible with our family weekly. We read the Bible chapter by chapter, verse by verse, and divide the weekly reading between all readers. Josiah started out reading a few verses, and now he can split the reading more evenly with the family. He is proud of this accomplishment and always volunteers to read first.

It’s great that Josiah and Serenity have each other as siblings and friends because they motivate each other. Serenity is a joyful new reader that loves a challenge and learning new things. You can feel her excitement when she sounds out each word and reads each sentence. She runs home after school, ready to read and share what she has learned, and it is exciting to witness. Serenity’s excitement has sparked a desire to read in Josiah. Instead of me having to tell Josiah to read, he lines up after Serenity to read to me. He eagerly assists Serenity with any word she feels she can’t sound out.

Our oldest son, Caleb, benefits anytime all electronics are taken away ( I believe this is true for all teenagers today). It improves his participation with the family and his desire to do other things like reading. Today he read books about making godly choices and what it takes to be successful as an entrepreneur. I saw the sparks in his eyes, but to keep that going, I know that as parents, we will have to continue the reading days and establish reading hours and have them often.

Today, I heard each of my children express that reading increases knowledge, and they all mentioned the importance of applying the knowledge they gained. Today was a good day, and we are grateful. I purchased new books for everyone. The children read their new books and challenged themselves by reading several books from my husband’s and my bookshelf. We enjoyed hot tea and healthy snacks while we read. We assisted each other and appreciated good discussions about the contents of our books.

“Black families read together. A family that reads together achieves together.”

Crystal Smith

on the banks of The Hudson!

What a joy, how amazing!
Best wishes for a long, happy life!

author: {profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/valkyriechan, URL=http://howtouseblackmagick.wordpress.com, last_name=P, ip_address=false, login=valkyriechan, site_ID=2.8541932E7, site_visible=true, nice_name=valkyriechan, avatar_URL=https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/f00db2e8ac4a894eb8b181616166f5b0?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, email=false, first_name=V, ID=2.807509E7, name=valkyriechan}
title: Hard Pills To Swallow
content:
Try as I might I do not understand these behavioral patterns of the family that I was both racist towards as a joke (I’m white too–i don’t rightly care about color, but I do make fun of stereotypes) and jealous of. My first instinct, the old habit, is too I wonder what the mom and dad sacrificed in order to receive complete nights of dark silent rest from before the hour of 10pm all the way to here it’s 5:30 in the morning and there’s still no sign of them getting up. But I recently learned no deals. I have been getting very imaginative about this maybe their family is the way it is because “everything changed after mom’s accident.” They seem privileged like somebody did military time or good college time or was lucky enough to get a job at a place that cared about their employees for a very very long time. and abuse never happens there. But the hard pill to swallow and that I know it’s true is it really doesn’t matter what you do in your life you can make all the right decisions and still life could turn out really bad.

I yelled at myself while I was alone in the bathroom yesterday I was so tired thoughts and memories of flashbacks pointed at myself in the mirror and screamed you! stop being sick! I’m so sick of this stupid shit! Reminded me of home.

Larry had gotten up to find a snack as usual and I got up to go to the bathroom. as I did I was wondering what in the world stops him from reaching out and holding his wife? Then I remember the pain. Then I remember I know the wife does things first she sets the stage for Miracles. Bible told me that it was the only thing that made me feel good about having to pull all of this energy out of my own butt. If I want sex I should just touch him. A lot. Pain relieving type touch and then maybe someday … I don’t think I’m still expecting and not loving he did say If you expect sex you have a problem and it’s not like I’m feeling horny or anything, just distant. This is the area that I didn’t know what to do about the sexual energy conservation. I’ll play with sparkles for now. I should probably grab a snack with him but I have dysregulated myself with all this stupid thinking. Best thing I can do now is yoga. Breathing. Lion’s breath don’t fail me now.

9 am they’ve gotten their whole camp pulled down and they’re leaving now I don’t know what kind of wonderful things they do all day I never got the chance to meet them. they would look over when I was playing flute or drum. Sigh. Wait A second the girls are gone and just the dad and one of the boys are taking everything down in such a timely manner that there’s no possible way that they can charge them for another day like they’ve done to us at every hotel we stayed at. Talk about trust with each other and talk about relying on each other. I bet the mom is mentally with it and presently there I bet that’s the only reason actually let’s get down to what I really think. Enough dysregulation about it.

I really think that they are privileged and I really think that privilege comes from some hereditary, and learned abolishment of abuse. I’m sure there’s never any abuse in their household I’m sure no one was raised with bad ideas about the world and if they were they were cast from the family. Yes I think that quote-unquote good families come from some magical place where everyone already knows how to be perfectly good and does it and those are the people that matter according to society anyway and that’s why I’m jealous of them Have I constructed this as well or is this really a thing? Are you from this type of family what is it like? Are you a unicorn?

Hmm it’s not like I’m really looking forward to dirty sweaty gritty standing in the forest sex especially considering has been five months and I had to wonder if I was pregnant for a freaking Week. Seriously not interested. I mean yeah he’s sexy yeah I love him yeah I’m proud of him yeah he’s taking care of the family so well but really this bites and there is just no hope of intimacy at all I actually think I’m going to go masturbate because yeah it’s true I am horny but then I’m gonna cry and then I’m gonna be sad and it’s gonna be a bad day This is in my hands now I mustn’t masturbate I failed it quitting smoking yesterday can I at least not god-damned be a stupid fucking idiot? Well I’m talking to myself like this it’s not going well I need to turn it around goodbye

author: {name=Alessandro Innocenti, URL=http://alessandroinnocenti.wordpress.com, last_name=Innocenti, avatar_URL=https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/524026c985969ce577dbfc6018ce2583?s=96&d=&r=G, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/alessandroinnocenti, nice_name=alessandroinnocenti, login=alessandroinnocenti, email=false, ID=5.4934033E7, site_visible=true, site_ID=5.7474717E7, first_name=Alessandro, ip_address=false}
title: Marital status
content:
Why women file for divorce more than men

The decision to end a marriage is often difficult, and couples may spend months, or even years, soul-searching before calling it quits. But when it comes to initiating a split, there’s a clear pattern in who makes the final call. In Western heterosexual relationships, women catalyse an enormous proportion of divorces. In the US specifically, where no-fault divorce is legal in all 50 sates, some estimates put the figure at 70%; this rises to a staggering 90% when women are college educated. In the UK, ONS statistics showed women petitioned for 62% of divorces in England and Wales in 2019. ….[READ]

author: {ID=1.58492688E8, site_visible=true, ip_address=false, site_ID=1.62962016E8, avatar_URL=https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/d161a4328015679f84d7e0cb4e6ed3e6?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, email=false, last_name=Aldred, login=lifelessmuddled, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/lifelessmuddled, nice_name=lifelessmuddled, name=lifelessmuddled, URL=http://lifelessmuddled.wordpress.com, first_name=Toni}
title: Mourning and homeless?
content:
I don’t really know where to begin with this. On the 4th of may my mother-in-law passed away. She was diagnosed with non Hodgkin’s lymphoma in December 2021. Chemo was started but caused deterioration of her other conditions. My husband, myself and our 3 children (11,9 and7) cared for her. We were given one care visit a day from the local council, until a month before her death when it was increased to 3 visits. So we carried the caring duties between us. Of course other family members came when they were able to. 2 weeks before her death she went into St Raphael’s hospice for palliative care. The final week of this my husband stayed every night with her. So in all this year so far has been difficult in all kinds of ways.

Since my mother-in-law passed our local council have informed us we are unlikely to be able to remain in the home with lived with her. My husband has lived in this house for 32 years, myself 11 and my children their entire lives. The stress has been immense, especially on top of our grief. The health repercussions have been felt by all of us. We’ve spoken to everybody we can and reached a point where we can do no more without any legal dates for eviction being given to us, they say we cannot apply for succession but the reasons make no sense. We really are in no man’s land whilst planning a funeral.

So as I write this we are currently clearing and packing our home, with possibly nowhere to go. We have contacted our local MP to appeal to the council on our behalf but are not holding out much hope. I’ve also had to give in and apply for Pip, due to the effect this situation has had on my chronic health conditions. So we are mourning and facing homelessness within the next few weeks… sometime life really is shit….

title: Grateful
content:
I am grateful.

I am calm and happy.

Yesterday I had food with family My little sister and her fiancé, with my folks and a little one. The weather was warm and glorious. The coffee great. And that was before I met up with them. It was wonderful too to be connected with my big sister. Sending her the pic and love while she travels back to the UK, through Paris.

author: {first_name=Per Gunnar, email=false, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/perjonsson, avatar_URL=https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/cbabaea0fa98692d00130498d7ac5d7c?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, login=perjonsson, last_name=Jönsson, URL=http://pgsramblings.wordpress.com, ID=1.6730963E7, site_visible=true, nice_name=perjonsson, site_ID=4.6131732E7, name=Per G Jönsson, ip_address=false}
title: Weekend, time to kill a cow.
content:
Well, I left the actual killing to whoever provides the meat for the butcher at my local store but me and Timothy did our best to help in destroying the evidence.

Whoever manages the meat section of my local store has upped his game quite a lot recently. When I was there a couple of weeks ago the entire section for over the counter meat was removed so I actually became a bit worried that it was removed permanently and they were going to go down the drain of only selling pre-packed meat. After all, in Macron’s and EC’s France less and less people can afford to spend money on good quality fresh food, restaurants and other things that was once part of the French culture.

}" data-image-title="A nice slab of dead cow for supper." data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://perjonsson.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img-20220514-0218.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://perjonsson.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img-20220514-0218.jpg?w=1024" src="https://perjonsson.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img-20220514-0218.jpg?w=300" alt="" class="wp-image-11243" srcset="https://perjonsson.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img-20220514-0218.jpg?w=300 300w, https://perjonsson.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img-20220514-0218.jpg?w=600 600w, https://perjonsson.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img-20220514-0218.jpg?w=150 150w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px" />

Anyway, I got a really nice 4 cm thick slab of Cote de Boeuf which I put on the barbeque and cooked really slowly for supper yesterday and served with just some fries and a tomato/onion/sweet corn salad. It was great. Really tender and Timothy was happy because he got a big bone to chew on. With around 27-28 degrees we are dining on the balcony of course.

After we had finished eating and cleared the table Timothy wanted to watch a movie, specifically he wanted to re-watch Pacific Rim. That movie really has a ridiculous, totally illogical piece of shit story but who cares? Giant robots fighting giant monsters, nuff said.

Well, now it is Sunday. I have already done the grocery shopping for today so I’m going to have a mostly relaxing day and later this afternoon I’m going to start to complain that tomorrow is Monday.

author: {nice_name=rodkersh1948, site_ID=9.8414711E7, avatar_URL=https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/92a9a454470b7fbb8cdb8b8619bd364c?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, last_name=Kersh, site_visible=true, email=false, ID=9.3605563E7, first_name=Rod, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/rodkersh1948, ip_address=false, login=rodkersh1948, URL=http://almondemotion.wordpress.com, name=rodkersh1948}
title: Psychoneuroimmunology and all that
content:
I wasn’t going to write anything today.

Not many people read my blog about long-distance relationships.

I get all the data.

Nothing personally identifiable just country and number.

Yesterday didn’t seem to connect.

I had one ‘like’ on Twitter – thanks Debbie.

The first time I heard about Psychoneuroimmunology (PNI) was back in 1994 when I was writing my Bachelor’s thesis. The topic was Near Death Experiences (NDE’s). I will cover this in a blog one day although I am not as interested in the subject now as much as I was in my early 20’s.

NDE’s are described by people who either encounter death or come very close, for example during cardiac arrest, shock, anaphylaxis or some other trauma.

There are lots of theories as to what is going-on.

I prefer the one which talks about the stimulation of excitatory neurones in the brain that generate complex hallucinations.

The idea being, or, perhaps the associated idea, is that these experience relate to the origins of the human propensity to belief.

PNI is related as it is the inter-relationship between the psyche, that is, the mind, neurology, or the white and grey matter in your head, including the peripheral nervous system (the nerves running into your eyes, fingers and toes) and, immunology, the body’s defence mechanisms.

If you layer on top of this our recent and growing understanding of the human gut-microbiome, you are getting somewhere, approaching the complexity.

It’s funny.

I remember being fascinated by PNI back in the 90’s. There were a few articles around – this was the dawn of the internet and we didn’t have Google Scholar. I was desperate to find people to talk to about this, I even considered it something I could get into as a career.

It wasn’t big in the UK and I became interested in other things, first medicine then older people.

Jumping forward 15 years, I met at an event Claudius, a South African thinker-cum expert in the work of Jan Smuts, Holism, Spiral Dynamics and PNI.

And now, I am thinking about this again.

There is a developing field of Functional Medicine in the UK, this is doctor and other scientists who are investigating and supporting people who have symptoms that lack an obvious physical cause.

For example, headaches when the brain scans, lumbar puncture and blood tests are normal, odd rashes, tingling in the fingers, unsteadiness, upset bowels and bladder that after extensive investigation look and appear to function just like everyone else’s bowels and bladder, yet they seem to work differently or at least provide the person affected with significant symptoms of pain, urgency, discomfort that other so-called ‘normals’ don’t experience.

This is something I have covered before so I won’t go into the details.

Here is more!

I was talking with my brother yesterday.

He has a hard time.

He is recently retired and struggling with arthritis affecting his hip and back. He has already, in his early 60’s had his first hip replacement and is scheduled for another.

This is all frustrating for my brother, as he has been very active all his life, always, running, cycling, skiing, that kind of thing.

Nothing is particularly surprising about any of this and you might think it odd for me to mention him in a blog about PNI.

Well, you see, despite his new hip and his old bad one and constant, severe pain that limits him and interferes with his sleep, a month ago he was off in the alps skiing. Yes, skiing.

He plays a weekly game of tennis.

He gets out an about on his bike.

And yet, at other times he has terrible, activity-limiting arthritis.

He told me when he was skiing all his pains disappeared.

I reminded him of our mum.

She had awful arthritis affecting both her knees.

Given all her other health problems she was never fit enough for surgery and so she had to put-up with the aches and pains and limited mobility.

Once a week she would attend a social in Glasgow. She loved to dance. She would dance for hours.

I recall, twenty or thirty years ago my mum experiencing terrible feet pain. She found it difficult to walk. I get this as well from time to time. One day, I need to hobble, especially in the morning, other days, nothing.

My mum’s foot pain just disappeared one day.

We have had all the tests. There is no rheumatoid or other funny inflammatory condition, x-rays are normal and all that.

Just pain sometimes and at others nothing.

Very dependent on the circumstances and my mood.

Not necessarily a bad, worried or anxious mood, just, mood. My specific demeanour on the day.

I said to my brother, ‘perhaps your pain is psychosomatic’ – this another name for functional.

He didn’t agree.

I described my hay-fever.

‘That’s caused by pollen,’ he said.

And yet, I have rhinorrhoea, that is, a runny nose that can happen at any time through the year, often precipitated by changes in my mental state. Pollen can affect me, mostly not.

It’s a funny old world.

They say there are as many neurones in your gut as in your brain, just as there are more bacteria in your gut than in your entire body.

I don’t know the specifics and these would be difficult to count, and yet, things are not as they seem.

We tend to believe in a concrete world. In the West at least. What you see is what you get. Spirituality is on the wane. Religious, transcendental or mystical experiences are niche, particularly for concrete thinkers like my brother.

PNI sort of addresses this.

It says that our psychology – what we think, feel and imagine is dependent not only upon our neurones, the electrons zipping through clouds of fat in our bodies but our immunity, all the cell signallers, the cytokines, antibodies and cell signalling-factors that keep us health and can on occasion turn on us, as in auto-immune conditions like rheumatoid or lupus.

We are the finite of our bodies and we are the infinite of our minds.

We are a walking anachronism.

And that explains it.

That we are for the most, at least at times, inexplicable.

We still don’t have enough understanding of ourselves to know what causes what and why we feel the way we do.

It is fine if you can climb into the flow, lose yourself in the TV or football or a book, if you are stuck inside, particularly if you are trapped in your body and the only way out is to walk in circles, that is when PNI strikes, it is when a NDE is an interesting diversion. When functional becomes our everyday.

Go well.

We are the finite of our bodies and we are the infinite of our minds.

We are a walking anachronism.

author: {nice_name=annalouisesmit, name=Anna Smit, site_ID=1.87608595E8, login=annalouisesmit, ID=1.6498918E7, first_name=Anna, last_name=Smit, ip_address=false, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/annalouisesmit, site_visible=true, email=false, avatar_URL=https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/8a3c74af2d1ca92d62dd490b46ab448d?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, URL=http://shalomaleh.wordpress.com}
title: Unfurling [Republished]
content:
In the month of May, I committed to sharing posts from others that have encouraged, inspired and challenged me. But today on my Mum’s 68th birthday (my Mum went to be with Jesus April 8th, 2014), the LORD again returned this post to me – because one of you liked it (thank you for being God’s gift!!) – and I knew I had to share it with you all again – a third time because of what just unfolded.

When I looked to see what post was being liked, I was so overwhelmed. Why? Because Bettie had just eerily emailed me of something so similar unfolding for her: as God placed a rainbow before her, the first she’s seen since her move, when she so needed God’s reminder that when we are faithless, He is the God who is faithful FOR us.

And then as I listened to the song I had included here, I decided to send it to a friend in Washington state, but God at the last moment brought another friend in Indiana to mind also, so I sent it to her too. What I didn’t know is that her Mama went to be with Jesus hours earlier – and now my dear friend was facing her very first night without her there, after months of caring for her elderly Mama in her own home. As Indiana slept but my friend couldn’t in her grief, the Holy Spirit compelled me in the Netherlands to send that song – showing her and me how deeply our God loves us and how PRESENT He is. Just as the song says, it is truly our Jesus who makes our faith to stand. May our God overwhelm you too today by the power of His love and the HOPE that is ours in Christ Jesus.

Shalom Aleh

On a day of fresh loss and grief for my little family, only Jesus could have had someone visit this post and have me return to re-read it only hours before that fresh loss came. It was one of numerous ways the Spirit of God revealed His nearness to me- in advance of today’s loss, preparing my heart to see and receive His compassion for our whole family.

May it bless your hearts too, and help you to see and remember God’s nearness to you through your own loss and grief also. I bless you to see details in your past you hadn’t noticed before, whereby God’s nearness to you and your loved ones becomes even more palpable to you. He truly is so very present to each one of us.

Welcome toDay 4 ofPart 6‘sChapter 1ofArise and Shine. Today,Anna is bringing forward the…

author: {name=Dr Chinwe C, ID=1.01701942E8, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/christiesilas, nice_name=christiesilas, site_visible=true, email=false, first_name=Chinwe, site_ID=1.07619197E8, ip_address=false, URL=http://christiesilas.wordpress.com, last_name=Njoku, login=christiesilas, avatar_URL=https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/79fd8d8b1f53e983835ad692bcf1d652?s=96&d=identicon&r=G}
title: Handling Someone Who Demands Defference Without Creating Bad Energy Around You.
content:
Have you ever been firm and direct with someone older? And it backfired? Even though you were legally and morally right?

If you’re of African heritage, you probably have experienced this. You must jump when asked.

My dad raised us up very different to the typical Nigerian family. We were not allowed to call older siblings “Sister or Brother XYZ.” Everyone was on first name basis.

No kneeling or prostrating to greet anyone. Not even them. Shaking hands was very acceptable. You better speak out, was my mum’s mantra.

But issues arose when interacting with other older Africans who expected to be greeted knees to the floor or face to the ground and to be deferred to. Even in inconvenience.

How were we to navigate this?

For me, I got into ‘trouble’ because I just wouldn’t.

But like the Bible says, wisdom is profitable to direct. I soon learned how to manage their egos while still being true to myself.

As I read the story of Gideon in the Bible on recently, I got my Biblical backing for this way of managing these people.

The men of Ephraim had accused Gideon of not calling them to the war against the Midianites.

‘The Ephraimites said to him, “Why have you done such a thing to us? You did not summon us when you went to fight the Midianites!” They argued vehemently with him.’ Judges 8:1.

Gideon’s response?

‘He said to them, “Now what have I accomplished compared to you? Even Ephraim’s leftover grapes are better quality than Abiezer’s harvest! It was to you that God handed over the Midianite generals, Oreb and Zeeb! What did I accomplish to rival that?” When he said this, they calmed down.’ Judges 8:12, 3.

Did you see that he barely mentioned the thing they were angry with him for?

And what has grapes have to do with battles? But food has a way of calming things down, I suppose.

So, how does this look practically?

Read the full blog and sign up to be the first to continue to enjoy my blogs and updates at my new website here.

author: {login=kathleenchamberlin7, last_name=Chamberlin, ID=1.67017949E8, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/kathleenchamberlin7, first_name=Kathleen, nice_name=kathleenchamberlin7, avatar_URL=https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/8c52e300055d9db8277c8506b3e948e3?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, site_ID=1.65555816E8, ip_address=false, email=false, site_visible=true, URL=http://kchamberlinwriter.wordpress.com, name=Kathleen Chamberlin}
title: Showers of Blessings
content: Sometimes—and I am ashamed to admit it is very rare—I become overwhelmed by how blessed I am. Recent awareness of blessings started a few days ago as reminders arrived all around me like droplets of spring rain, refreshing my spirit and touching my heart.

}" data-image-title="pexels-george-dolgikh-giftpunditscom-2072160" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://kchamberlinwriter.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/pexels-george-dolgikh-giftpunditscom-2072160.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://kchamberlinwriter.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/pexels-george-dolgikh-giftpunditscom-2072160.jpg?w=1024" src="https://kchamberlinwriter.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/pexels-george-dolgikh-giftpunditscom-2072160.jpg?w=1024" alt="" class="wp-image-1919" width="528" height="352" srcset="https://kchamberlinwriter.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/pexels-george-dolgikh-giftpunditscom-2072160.jpg?w=1024 1024w, https://kchamberlinwriter.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/pexels-george-dolgikh-giftpunditscom-2072160.jpg?w=528 528w, https://kchamberlinwriter.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/pexels-george-dolgikh-giftpunditscom-2072160.jpg?w=1056 1056w, https://kchamberlinwriter.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/pexels-george-dolgikh-giftpunditscom-2072160.jpg?w=150 150w, https://kchamberlinwriter.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/pexels-george-dolgikh-giftpunditscom-2072160.jpg?w=300 300w, https://kchamberlinwriter.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/pexels-george-dolgikh-giftpunditscom-2072160.jpg?w=768 768w" sizes="(max-width: 528px) 100vw, 528px" />

So where were the men? They joined us as we opened gifts, gathering on one edge of the patio like a Greek chorus. But this chorus was not accompanying the main show. They were all engaged in their own production. We later found out they had been torn away from a ball game. 

But it was all good! Because this writing is about all the women who have enriched my life in so many ways and how suddenly it came into focus. 

Thank you all, my beautiful sisterhood, for the texts, bouquets, gifts, and heartful written words. I cannot imagine life without you.
excerpt: Sometimes—and I am ashamed to admit it is very rare—I become overwhelmed by how blessed I am. Recent awareness of blessings started a few days ago as reminders arrived all around me like droplets of spring rain, refreshing my spirit and touching my heart.  Last Friday, an unexpected bouquet arrived from a young woman (she […]

author: {name=DebH, avatar_URL=https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/19cf0df4f3570b965e1b5a6bf8c39b1f?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, last_name=, first_name=Debjani, ID=1.85084485E8, login=debjanih, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/debjanih, email=false, site_visible=true, ip_address=false, site_ID=2.06303377E8, nice_name=debjanih, URL=http://dina936070497.wordpress.com}
title: A love like never before
content:
It’s hard.

Love is hard.

Have you ever had a sibling? I have an older sister. And it can’t compare.

I always kept wanting to feel that same love for someone else. For my mom. Or my dad. Or even my childhood best friend. She kept asking me if I loved her for years and when she finally stopped asking, I started saying it.

But I don’t know if that was the truth or a lie. Was it? But it’s unmistakable with my sister. Whoever she is, whatever kind of person she is, she’s my sister. And that actually explains everything. It’s cliche and ironic. But it really does.

I feel like it’s encoded in my DNA. Like it’s a basic make up of who I am. I don’t know if she feels the same way. If she feels like every other love feels shallow in comparison.

I feel like I can’t love at all. When I think about it, the fondness I feel for my friends, the feeling I get around my mother, it’s not the same.

I’m afraid my whole life will be the same. I’ll want to love someone the same way I love my sister and it’ll be like reaching for the moon. I’ll keep wanting it and it will never happen.

I was born this way, and I’ll probably die this way too. I don’t think I mind it much, to be honest.

title: FanExpo 2022 with my daughters Alyssah and Arleenah
content:
I spent the day with my daughter’s Alyssah and Arleenah. We attended FanExpo St. Louis. We had a wonderful time! 🥰

Alyssah’s Cosplay: Kirari Momobami, Kakegurui
My cosplay: Mimori Tougou, Yuki Yuna is a Hero
Arleenah didn’t play with us this time 😜

title: Why do I hate being with my relatives
content:
}" data-image-title="c0d8ed8a0adebb47e44d39503c7eb273" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://justrandomstuffthatcrossmymind.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/c0d8ed8a0adebb47e44d39503c7eb273.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://justrandomstuffthatcrossmymind.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/c0d8ed8a0adebb47e44d39503c7eb273.jpg?w=735" src="https://justrandomstuffthatcrossmymind.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/c0d8ed8a0adebb47e44d39503c7eb273.jpg?w=735" alt="" class="wp-image-12" srcset="https://justrandomstuffthatcrossmymind.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/c0d8ed8a0adebb47e44d39503c7eb273.jpg 735w, https://justrandomstuffthatcrossmymind.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/c0d8ed8a0adebb47e44d39503c7eb273.jpg?w=150 150w, https://justrandomstuffthatcrossmymind.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/c0d8ed8a0adebb47e44d39503c7eb273.jpg?w=300 300w" sizes="(max-width: 735px) 100vw, 735px" />

So my phone has 7% charge left when I starting to write my first ever blog. Today is Sunday.

As you can see from the title. I hate being with my relatives(family in general). I think it’s not really a good thing. Because everyone else seems to be just fine when I sweat so much in family occasions. I don’t like it very much.

It’s not like my relatives are annoying. I don’t think of them as untolerable creatures I want to avoid. In fact, I don’t hate them at all. I just hate being with them. I hate how it makes me feel.

And the situation has been getting worse since childhood. I have always been so awkward around them. Maybe I unintentionally disrespected them sometimes too. Now, they hate me. They say, “she’s so weird” in front of my face so many times. So now it’s even harder for me to interact with them.

I have this cousin, he’s one year older than me. Next Sunday is his birthday. And all of my family members are supposed to go. I don’t want to go. Not because I don’t like them or I want to disrespect them, but because I know that if I go, I will feel so awkward for no reason and I will hate being there and think that it’s better to unexist. Thoughts like this creep me out.

But I guess I will have to attend his birthday party anyway. Oh wait, my phone is dying. It has 1% charge now. I’ll write more later.

You might be thinking “why would I read your blog?” You don’t have to. I will just write random things on here, share stuff that I don’t share with anyone, or something that crossed my mind during physics class, or while watching pride and Prejudice. If you want to listen you can read.

🙂

title: Gem
content:
This beautiful Goddess is Gem. I have just finished a practice photoshoot and I can’t even CHOOSE the photo to share, so I shared THEM ALL! This beauty is just too beautiful not to share every single photo I take. I absolutely love her!

I will upload a few more of her in the next post. Thank you for looking. ❤

I hope you like her as much as I do

author: {URL=http://frankgphotography.wordpress.com, email=false, site_visible=true, site_ID=6.6263052E7, name=frankgphotography, last_name=G., avatar_URL=https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/7c8b020cd0b01ad265958c20d6f67a44?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, first_name=Frank, ip_address=false, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/frankfotos, login=frankfotos, nice_name=frankfotos, ID=6.3399026E7}
title: Canon 24mm HDR photos at heating plant
content:
}" data-image-title="Canon 24 Sony A6300 Heating plant session Nov 22 2019 pic3" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://cameragearreviewsbyfrank.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/canon-24-sony-a6300-heating-plant-session-nov-22-2019-pic3-srgb.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://cameragearreviewsbyfrank.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/canon-24-sony-a6300-heating-plant-session-nov-22-2019-pic3-srgb.jpg?w=1024" src="https://cameragearreviewsbyfrank.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/canon-24-sony-a6300-heating-plant-session-nov-22-2019-pic3-srgb.jpg?w=1024" alt="Heating plant hdr photo" class="wp-image-25" srcset="https://cameragearreviewsbyfrank.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/canon-24-sony-a6300-heating-plant-session-nov-22-2019-pic3-srgb.jpg?w=1024 1024w, https://cameragearreviewsbyfrank.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/canon-24-sony-a6300-heating-plant-session-nov-22-2019-pic3-srgb.jpg?w=2048 2048w, https://cameragearreviewsbyfrank.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/canon-24-sony-a6300-heating-plant-session-nov-22-2019-pic3-srgb.jpg?w=150 150w, https://cameragearreviewsbyfrank.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/canon-24-sony-a6300-heating-plant-session-nov-22-2019-pic3-srgb.jpg?w=300 300w, https://cameragearreviewsbyfrank.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/canon-24-sony-a6300-heating-plant-session-nov-22-2019-pic3-srgb.jpg?w=768 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" />

I edit the HDR in Photomatix Pro 5. I would then export to Lightroom for some minor adjustments. Note that the photo were rendered out at sRGB in order to keep the color looking the same during export. Using Pro Photo RGB was showing the images washed out and using sRGB rendered in its right color space.

The adapter on the camera is Fotodiox Canon EOS to Sony Emount. They make great adapters for a wide range of cameras. I highly recommend them if you are looking to mix and match lenses.

If you have any questions regarding the settings or are interested in the gear I used here, you can visit the camera gear listings below. These are Amazon Affiliate links and they help me keep bringing you amazing content.

The tripod I used was easy to carry and made set up a breeze

My camera of choice on this trip was the Sony A6300 and it made it easy to capture the images you see here.

The Canon 24mm Lens can be used for both indoor and Outdoors

The program I used to edit the image in HDR is called Photomatix Pro. You can view below.

I hope you found this information useful, I will provide more in the upcoming post. ~Frank
excerpt: The Canon lens featured here is fantastic for landscape and indoor photography. I had the opportunity to photograph inside a heating plant and I decided to use this lens to capture the entirety of the building. The indoor environment presented a challenge. I decided a tripod and the hdr method would most likely give me […]

title: Spring Debutante
content:
This year, there’s only one owlet at the Great Horned Owl household. Since the coming-out party, the family’s debutante is poised to become the star of the woods. Birding paparazzi converge and they’re not disappointed.

But first, a Where’s Waldo quiz for you. Can you spot mama and owlet on this tree:

author: {site_ID=2.3058057E7, avatar_URL=https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/0ab369e2c2aca69b7a3a889935af944d?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, name=derekmaul, email=false, login=derekmaul, last_name=Maul, ID=2.3338545E7, first_name=Derek, site_visible=true, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/derekmaul, URL=http://derekmaul.wordpress.com, ip_address=false, nice_name=derekmaul}
title: Early Light, and frustrated but thankful hearts
content:
}" data-image-title="IMG_1801 (1)" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://derekmaul.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_1801-1.jpeg?w=300" data-large-file="https://derekmaul.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_1801-1.jpeg?w=1024" src="https://derekmaul.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_1801-1.jpeg?w=1024" alt="" class="wp-image-114178" width="347" height="261" srcset="https://derekmaul.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_1801-1.jpeg?w=347 347w, https://derekmaul.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_1801-1.jpeg?w=694 694w, https://derekmaul.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_1801-1.jpeg?w=150 150w, https://derekmaul.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/img_1801-1.jpeg?w=300 300w" sizes="(max-width: 347px) 100vw, 347px" />

Rebekah and I are more than a little bummed this morning not to be over in Wilson. We are thankful that the prognosis is good – inasmuch as there is no need for surgery – but healing is just going to take too long, and requires her to stay off her feet, and there’s not a thing we can do to alter this tedious timeline.

So at 7:30, rather than jumping in the car and driving over for Early Light worship, I took my first cup of coffee out onto the deck and looked out over this lovely, peaceful neighborhood.

My personal devotional thoughts sounded something like this: There are a lot of “whys” I don’t understand, Lord, and I would be lying if I said we weren’t frustrated and sad this morning. Regardless, I am grateful for this beautiful new day, and seeing the sunlight pass through the millions of leaves gives me joy and a feeling of deep peace. There is so much around me to be thankful for. There is so much of life that is good.

We plan to join our Hudson Memorial Presbyterian Church family for livestream worship at 10:30. Public worship, together in the context of community, is vitally important.

But my heart had already turned to worship first thing today, and God’s love, majesty, faithfulness, light, grace, and goodness have been front and center since that first sip of coffee, out on the deck, where everything else becomes framed in terms of our fundamental calling to “Love God and to enjoy God forever.”

Enjoy this beautiful May Sunday – DEREK

author: {name=resarfpoetry, login=resarfpoetry, avatar_URL=https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/0558d2eaf0a6bdd6946894d1c341e673?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, first_name=duncan, site_visible=true, nice_name=resarfpoetry, ip_address=false, email=false, URL=http://resarfpoetry.wordpress.com, ID=8.6206819E7, site_ID=1.15144088E8, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/resarfpoetry, last_name=f-m}
title: middle may not march
content:
~

middle may not march ( hcram ton yam elddim )

…

red shepherd sunrise

warning the morning

      sights for sore iris

      & drooping bluebell

ends in beginnings

bring your own picnic

      pencils in cases

      pythagorean

glistening magpies

pied like a wagtail

      pipers inside us

      miming the high notes

playing the rhubarb

fooling the pudding

      pissing the parcel

      fluttering butter

spring is a fucker

further’s a murmur

      chasing a sun day

      whistle a willow

walking in warbles

spooling in cagoules

      piriton’s flashbacks

      sneezing the pastures

yes is a nomad

walk upon england

      blake is awakened

      so sod the machine

newton is sleeping

twofold’s a thistle

      beulah beckons

      & god save the green

…

author: {ID=1.22093513E8, site_ID=1.29569895E8, URL=http://nacforadventure.wordpress.com, name=nacforadventure, email=false, first_name=, site_visible=true, nice_name=nacforadventure, ip_address=false, login=nacforadventure, avatar_URL=https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/eba2f4804cec3c88774b7ee01007de02?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/nacforadventure, last_name=}
title: YouTube Video: A Chaotic Ski and Photoshoot Day Vlog
content:
Welcome back to the latest hectic day in the life of Nic and AJ as we head up to the mountain to grab some shots of the 2023 Liberty Origin Backcountry 106 skis.

We end up getting some rad photos (Spoiler alert!!), but we go through a lot to get there. From forgetting some vital ski equipment to heavy and corny snow conditions to an almost-core shot, we take you through a May ski and shoot day in the Wasatch backcountry.

Thanks so much to Nic for snapping all the photos, and shoutout to Mother Nature who let us enjoy a beautiful day when we were expecting overcast and cloudy.

Your nacforadventurers and grateful humans,

AJ and Nic

title: Flower of the week – week 20
content:
A fairly easy choice this week – these have been opening gradually over the last couple of weeks and now there are several, providing an emphatic full stop at the end of the main flowerbed. I should really have more alliums. I do have a few others that haven’t flowered this year as they didn’t go in the ground early enough, but they have put out some leaves so I’m hopeful for flowers next year.

Alliums are onions (allium is Latin for garlic) grown for their stunning flowers rather than their bulbs. They are drought-tolerant and flower in late spring/early summer. We’ve only had them for a few years but I do look forward to their flowering season.

title: Extension
content:
}" data-image-title="country" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://snarmadhaa.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/country.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://snarmadhaa.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/country.jpg?w=1024" src="https://snarmadhaa.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/country.jpg" alt="photo of the brownish countryside as seen from the car, driving from Adelaide to Auburn, South Australia" class="wp-image-20144" />

Acres and acres
of barnyard brown stretching out—
welcome to country.
excerpt: Acres and acresof barnyard brown stretching out—welcome to country.

title: A Drive in the Country, part 1
content: This post, and the upcoming part 2, showcase just a touch of the beautiful, wide-open country near my home in Kansas. After living in a very crowded Southern California for decades, there’s nothing quite like vast expanses of ranch and farm land. ~SueBee

author: {site_visible=true, email=false, last_name=Kanigan, avatar_URL=https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/554cf62b7c5bd4cf2e14d29d9f5b726e?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, ID=2.7636246E7, ip_address=false, login=davidkanigan, first_name=David, site_ID=2.8060549E7, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/davidkanigan, name=Live & Learn, nice_name=davidkanigan, URL=http://davidkanigan.com}
title: Walking. Sunday Morning. DK Saves.
content:
}" data-image-title="horseshoecrab1-fin" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://davidkanigan.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/horseshoecrab1-fin.jpg?w=270" data-large-file="https://davidkanigan.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/horseshoecrab1-fin.jpg?w=923" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-58661" src="https://davidkanigan.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/horseshoecrab1-fin.jpg" alt="" width="100%" />

Let’s just get to the punch line of this story. (Oh, btw, it’s 724 consecutive (almost) days on my Daybreak walk at Cove Island Park. Like in a Row.)

There it lay.  At the end of my walk. An Atlantic Horseshoe Crab. Flat on its back. Nothing delicate or beautiful about this alien-looking thing. I’m sure its Mother loved it.

Its Telson was slapping back and forth. (Telson = Tail.  And of course I didn’t know that it was called a Telson. Googled it.) Creature was caught way up on the beach, tide shot out, and here we are. In Deep Shit. And you thought you were having a bad day?

I’m staring at the Telson (and yes, I’m going to keep repeating Telson like some career Marine Biologist)…and I’m wondering if its Telson carries electrical current. Or like a skunk, backs up its ass and spews sulfuric sh*t all over my camera gear.  Or like a Cephalopod, shoots ink all over me, seeping into my skin, and poisons me.

Stamford Daily reports: “Idiot found dead on Cove Island Beach trying to save Horseshoe Crab. Good News though, his death wasn’t for naught. It was notable that he was found flat on his back, like the Horseshoe Crab he was trying to save – – his mouth wide open, teeth blackened with Cephalopod ink, with his arms straight up in the air, because no matter what, the camera gear needed to remain undamaged.”

Per NatGeo, Horseshoe Crabs have been around for 450 million years. And here I am, Human, around an eye twitch of that time, trying to assess the probability of being electrocuted or poisoned.  I could have pulled out my smartphone and Googled it to be sure…but this gives you a full measure of this man…not a lot of depth, prefers to let the mystery of life and its currents drag him along to the finish. And ‘hopefully’ that Finish isn’t this morning.

So, there I am. Staring down on Horsey.  His limbs and Telson desperately seeking salvation.

Do the right thing?

Save yourself?

Who’s going to know?

Just keep walking.

It’s been such a nice, quiet, Sunday morning walk. Up to now.

I turn my back and walk.

And walk.

I’m listening to Delia Ephron’s new memoir “Left on Tenth. A Second Chance at Life“: “I went from believing nothing has any meaning to believing that everything does. Even though I’m often not sure what the meaning is.“

A Second Chance at Life. Horsey’s Second Chance.

I stop. Turn around.  G*d Damn it.

I approach Horsey.  And he’s still flailing.

I put the camera gear down.

I unleash the backpack and put it down.

I roll up the sleeves on my jacket. If there’s electric current, let it have a clear, direct shot right to my veins. No suffering. Just shock. Death in < 3 seconds.

There’s still time to just let this all go. For God Sakes, just grab him.

I gingerly grab his Telson.

No shock. Yet.

No squirting ink. Yet.

His arms and legs are now frantically flailing. Wonder if the Telson breaks off like a Salamander to save himself. Or if the Telson is some crucial body organ, and I’ve mortally damaged him by not grabbing him by his shell. GOOD GOD MAN, JUST DO IT.

I walk out in the water, Horsey-by-the-Tail, deep enough for him not to get trapped again. I gently set him down.

There’s no movement for a time.

I stand over to watch him. Prayer time?

Then his Telson twitches.  Right, and then left.  And then there was movement!  Life!

I watch over him for a few minutes, he’s swimming as if nothing happened to him, sniffing around the ocean bottom.  And he’ll go swimming for another 200 million years.

I traipse out of the water, stomping down on the beach to shake the sand from my boots.

Next Sunday morning, we’ll leave this saving lives to Jesus.

This is just too damn stressful.

author: {ID=6.3424587E7, last_name=Adams, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/mgadams1970, login=mgadams1970, first_name=Mark, name=Mark G.Adams, nice_name=mgadams1970, ip_address=false, URL=http://onecameraonelens.com, email=false, avatar_URL=https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/41d560f01af367dcbce237dea862c7d2?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, site_visible=true, site_ID=1.79728401E8}
title: Using the 7.5mm fisheye lens as a rectilinear wide-angle lens (with images from Laugharne Castle)
content:
I haven’t used my TTArtisan 7.5mm fisheye lens enough over the last few months, and it’s not because I don’t like it. I really do love the lens, how it performs and how it displays colours, contrast and sharpness. It’s because I don’t always want everything to look like a fisheye. I know it’s easy enough to convert from fisheye to rectilinear, but I haven’t been in that mindset for one simple reason which I will discuss below.

I love my images to usually be one of three aspect ratios; either 3:2 or 5:4 and occasionally I will also choose 1:1 square format. Anything wider I tend to dismiss, but after a lot of thought and experimenting I think I will have to change the way I think about this.

I have created three quick actions in Photoscape X Pro to convert fisheye photographs. I call them simply “Fisheye Correct 1 (Super wide)”, “Fisheye Correct 2 (Cropped straighter)” and “Fisheye Correct 3 (Wide & stretched)”.

Here is an example of the original images:

I know not everyone is a lover of fisheye lenses, so I hope that I can sell their praises by showing just how versatile they can be, and why, if you can get one, they are worth every penny that you spend!

I hope you enjoyed, please feel free to comment, like and subscribe!

Thank you those who have supported me. If you’d like to contribute, I accept PayPal donations at mgadams1970@gmail.com. I am a fun loving snapper who runs a weekly meeting photography groups as well as numerous Facebook groups (Great Photography Walks South Wales and Fujifilm Lovers Worldwide Group). I also have a brand-new blog website dedicated to various other things which I like to call The Ramblings Of A Welshman. I hope you can join me there; you might find it interesting! You’ll find my YouTube Channel Here!
excerpt: I haven’t used my TTArtisan 7.5mm fisheye lens enough over the last few months, and it’s not because I don’t like it. I really do love the lens, how it performs and how it displays colours, contrast and sharpness. It’s because I don’t always want everything to look like a fisheye. I know it’s easy […]
