author: {name=kagould17, login=kagould17, email=false, site_visible=true, avatar_URL=https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/d70c1d7a65d44fae6885613b81f69d35?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, site_ID=1.93872112E8, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/kagould17, last_name=Gould, first_name=Allan, ID=7.5506999E7, URL=https://picturethis203532735.wordpress.com, nice_name=kagould17, ip_address=false}
title: Flashback – Japan 2009 – a Day with Friends in High Places
content:
All photos taken on September 19, 2009.

Way back in my first post on this series, I talked about Kunika, a home stay student that one of our dear friends, J had hosted for an entire school year. In the good old days of not knowing everyone’s E-mail address, we relied on snail mail to make the initial contact and let here when we were coming and asking if we could get together. As the day of our departure drew closer and closer, we still had not heard from her and we grew worried we would miss meeting up with her, altogether.

To continue reading, please click here.

Alternatively, click here to go to new Blog Site

author: {ID=1.38010268E8, email=false, name=philosophy through photography, first_name=Philo, avatar_URL=https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/d6b4faa95d8ce26724cc78dc200f07cd?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, site_visible=true, ip_address=false, URL=https://philosophyvia.photos, last_name=, login=philosophyviaphotos, nice_name=philosophyviaphotos, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/philosophyviaphotos, site_ID=1.45517641E8}
title: Beam
content:
BEAM

“Everyone conceals his own beam and notices the mote in the other people’s eyes” Maltese proverb

}" data-image-title="Roof" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://philosophyviaphotos.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/roof.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://philosophyviaphotos.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/roof.jpg?w=700" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-32945" src="https://philosophyviaphotos.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/roof.jpg" alt="Roof" width="700" height="436" srcset="https://philosophyviaphotos.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/roof.jpg 700w, https://philosophyviaphotos.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/roof.jpg?w=150&h=93 150w, https://philosophyviaphotos.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/roof.jpg?w=300&h=187 300w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" />

“A house is made with walls and beams

A home is built with love and dreams”

Ralph Waldo Emerson

Thank you for your visit.

Take care, my friend.

Namaste 🙏🙏🙏

Philo

You can check my other similar posts HERE

title: Homage to the Flower Moon
content: These images are taken in the Southern “courtyard”.

}" data-image-title="f6" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f6.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f6.jpg?w=1024" src="https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f6.jpg?w=900" alt="" class="wp-image-384" srcset="https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f6.jpg?w=900 900w, https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f6.jpg?w=1800 1800w, https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f6.jpg?w=150 150w, https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f6.jpg?w=300 300w, https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f6.jpg?w=768 768w, https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f6.jpg?w=1024 1024w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" />

}" data-image-title="f7" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f7.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f7.jpg?w=1024" src="https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f7.jpg?w=900" alt="" class="wp-image-385" srcset="https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f7.jpg?w=900 900w, https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f7.jpg?w=1800 1800w, https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f7.jpg?w=150 150w, https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f7.jpg?w=300 300w, https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f7.jpg?w=768 768w, https://traouandour.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/f7.jpg?w=1024 1024w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" />

This from the “bowl”. When we moved in that bed was completely overgrown. We found Acanthus hidden underneath. It has started to thrive. The one on the left has a moth on it. The spikes are about to flower and extend.
excerpt: These images are taken in the Southern “courtyard”. This from the “bowl”. When we moved in that bed was completely overgrown. We found Acanthus hidden underneath. It has started to thrive. The one on the left has a moth on it. The spikes are about to flower and extend.

author: {name=Aletta - nowathome, ID=5.1994248E7, URL=http://nowathome.wordpress.com, first_name=Aletta, last_name=Crous, ip_address=false, site_visible=true, email=false, login=nowathome, site_ID=5.4386126E7, nice_name=nowathome, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/nowathome, avatar_URL=https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/51f4ee57c2a3885b8bb184f3926d0ad4?s=96&d=https%3A%2F%2Fs0.wp.com%2Fi%2Fmu.gif&r=G}
title: PPAC # 46
content:
Marsha Ingrao from Always Write blog has an interesting challenge.

What PPAC is all about.

Public art is which encompasses any form of art you see in a public place, large or small, statues, murals, graffiti, gardens, Christmas lights, even buildings or bridges. The art should be visible from streets, sidewalks or outdoor public places

}" data-image-title="IMG_8715" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="

Lion Statue

" data-medium-file="https://nowathome.files.wordpress.com/2016/07/img_8715.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://nowathome.files.wordpress.com/2016/07/img_8715.jpg?w=1024" src="https://nowathome.files.wordpress.com/2016/07/img_8715.jpg?w=656" alt="" class="wp-image-9267" srcset="https://nowathome.files.wordpress.com/2016/07/img_8715.jpg?w=656 656w, https://nowathome.files.wordpress.com/2016/07/img_8715.jpg?w=1312 1312w, https://nowathome.files.wordpress.com/2016/07/img_8715.jpg?w=150 150w, https://nowathome.files.wordpress.com/2016/07/img_8715.jpg?w=300 300w, https://nowathome.files.wordpress.com/2016/07/img_8715.jpg?w=768 768w, https://nowathome.files.wordpress.com/2016/07/img_8715.jpg?w=1024 1024w" sizes="(max-width: 656px) 100vw, 656px" />

Topic Suggestions

  • Seasonal Displays
  • Graffiti
  • Statues and Sculptures
  • Collections
  • Store Windows
  • Car Shows
  • Artistic Construction (benches, buildings, bridges)
  • Wall Art (not just murals)

The art should be visible from streets, sidewalks or outdoor public places Topic […]

title: What Is Your Secret Destination?
content:
All journeys have secret destinations of which the traveler is unaware.

  • Martin Buber

}" data-image-title="cross_country_0818_2010_005-1" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://opreach.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/cross_country_0818_2010_005-1.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://opreach.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/cross_country_0818_2010_005-1.jpg?w=900" src="https://opreach.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/cross_country_0818_2010_005-1.jpg?w=900" alt="" class="wp-image-9426" srcset="https://opreach.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/cross_country_0818_2010_005-1.jpg 900w, https://opreach.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/cross_country_0818_2010_005-1.jpg?w=150 150w, https://opreach.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/cross_country_0818_2010_005-1.jpg?w=300 300w, https://opreach.files.wordpress.com/2022/04/cross_country_0818_2010_005-1.jpg?w=768 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" />

We are excited to offer a virtual retreat – a virtual pilgrimage – with Fr. Michael Fish, OSB Cam, entitled, Levanté 1. To learn about and/or register for Santa Sabina Center online retreats and offerings, please go to: http://www.santasabinacenter.org/retreats-page.

excerpt: The Matriarch. During the Spring and Summer months the Eastern Bluebirds rule the yard here in Bear Woods. No other birds get in their way, and no birds go near their house unless they want to feel the wrath. I think this is the 4th season with the current pair in the yard and their […]

author: {first_name=Daniel, URL=http://danielcpotts.wordpress.com, login=danielcpotts, ID=5.4908467E7, site_visible=true, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/danielcpotts, nice_name=danielcpotts, last_name=Potts, site_ID=5.7448757E7, name=danielcpotts, ip_address=false, avatar_URL=https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/1f2a19cebc4dbb36be662b2af7a2433c?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, email=false}
title: After You’ve Been Held
content:
After you’ve been held,
quietly, securely, lovingly,
at a time of deep unworthiness,
when you’ve felt the everlasting
arms of acceptance wrapping ‘round
even as you’ve trembled and wept,
then you’ll want to turn,
open-armed, open-handed,
to hold a hurting world.

author: {ip_address=false, name=BAISMAG, profile_URL=https://en.gravatar.com/magbais, email=false, site_ID=1.22680627E8, site_visible=true, last_name=, ID=1.15697079E8, URL=http://baismagcom.wordpress.com, first_name=, avatar_URL=https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/7c02411c42e5245157f5bf95003c2c98?s=96&d=identicon&r=G, nice_name=magbais, login=magbais}
title: Charity Ball 2022
content:
On Friday, countless IS students (and some non-IS friends) came together at PIP to support Milieudefensie, a Dutch charity working towards a cleaner and more sustainable world.


Themed ‘Enchanted Forest’, the Charity Ball was the perfect opportunity for students to dress up in their prettiest and magical suits, tops, and dresses. After kicking off the night with some appetizers, an auction took place. Outside, fairytale lights and a photobooth kept others entertained. Finally, pizza proved the perfect antidote to the alcohol that kept flowing.

title: Flashback – Japan 2009 – a Day with Friends in High Places
content:
All photos taken on September 19, 2021.

Way back in my first post on this series, I talked about Kunika, a home stay student that one of our dear friends, J had hosted for an entire school year. In the good old days of not knowing everyone’s E-mail address, we relied on snail mail to make the initial contact and let her know when we were coming and asking if we could get together. As the day of our departure drew closer and closer, we still had not heard from her and we grew worried we would miss meeting up with her, altogether.

At long last, I received an E-mail from Kunika, reading “Kunika is Alive”. The only mailing address we had was for her parents, who had moved not long ago. The letter had been held up, but was finally delivered. The parents let Kunika (now married and living elsewhere) know she had mail and the rest, as they say, is history.

We had arranged to meet at our hotel on this day to head off an adventure in Kamakura (separate posts) and then join Kunika and Masa for supper, back at their home. Masa was in the dentist chair in the morning, but would join us in Kamakura later in the day.

Picture of the Pont des rivières overt the Pike River near Notre-Dame-de Stanbridge. Built in 1884, it’s the last ”Howe” type covered bridge in the province of Quebec (still in use).

The Des Rivières Bridge is a civil engineering structure built in 1884. This 37.4 meters single-span bridge has a Howe-type structure with double diagonals made of wood and steel elements. It is covered with a facing of vertical planks with battening painted red and is topped with a roof with two straight sheet metal slopes. The structure rests on stone abutments. Located in a rural area, the Des Rivières Bridge spans the Brochets River, in the municipality of Notre-Dame-de-Stanbridge.(sourced Répertoire du patrimoine culturelle du Québec)

Photo du pont couvert Pont des rivières dans la municipalité de Notre-Dame-de-Standbridge. Construit en 1884, c’est le dernier pont couvert du type ” Howe” en utilisation au Québec.

Le pont de Des Rivières est un ouvrage de génie civil construit en 1884. Ce pont à travée unique de 37,4 mètres présente une structure de type Howe à diagonales doubles constituée d’éléments en bois et en acier. Il est couvert d’un parement en planches verticales à couvre-joints peint en rouge et il est coiffé d’un toit à deux versants droits en tôle. L’ouvrage repose sur des culées en pierre. Situé en milieu rural, le pont de Des Rivières enjambe la rivière aux Brochets, dans la municipalité de Notre-Dame-de-Stanbridge.(source Répertoire du patrimoine culturelle du Québec)

title: Grey Breath.
content:
}" data-image-title="0b999431-b623-4bbc-93d5-eeb593952662" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://siamorweng.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0b999431-b623-4bbc-93d5-eeb593952662.jpeg?w=169" data-large-file="https://siamorweng.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0b999431-b623-4bbc-93d5-eeb593952662.jpeg?w=576" src="https://siamorweng.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0b999431-b623-4bbc-93d5-eeb593952662.jpeg?w=576" alt="" class="wp-image-6119" srcset="https://siamorweng.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0b999431-b623-4bbc-93d5-eeb593952662.jpeg?w=576 576w, https://siamorweng.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0b999431-b623-4bbc-93d5-eeb593952662.jpeg?w=84 84w, https://siamorweng.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0b999431-b623-4bbc-93d5-eeb593952662.jpeg?w=169 169w, https://siamorweng.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0b999431-b623-4bbc-93d5-eeb593952662.jpeg?w=768 768w, https://siamorweng.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/0b999431-b623-4bbc-93d5-eeb593952662.jpeg 1024w" sizes="(max-width: 576px) 100vw, 576px" />

when we close our eyes at night,
it’s not only the moon that lets out
a sigh of relief but those
those too who stay awake at night,
ensuring our daylight will dance
many dances motivated by the moon,
those too spot a smile on their stagnant faces.

title: Are Workshops Helpful?
content: This past week, I attended a photography workshop. The subject was bird photography. It was held at a location known to be a key flyway for spring migrating birds here in Canada, particularly for warblers and related species.

}" data-image-title="64a9523-1" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://ninakirienkoblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/64a9523-1.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://ninakirienkoblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/64a9523-1.jpg?w=1024" src="https://ninakirienkoblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/64a9523-1.jpg?w=1024" alt="" class="wp-image-8127" srcset="https://ninakirienkoblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/64a9523-1.jpg?w=1024 1024w, https://ninakirienkoblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/64a9523-1.jpg?w=150 150w, https://ninakirienkoblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/64a9523-1.jpg?w=300 300w, https://ninakirienkoblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/64a9523-1.jpg?w=768 768w, https://ninakirienkoblog.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/64a9523-1.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" />

I have no doubt that my physical limitations on this latest workshop contributed to my feeling of a less than ideal experience. But it is also true that I was able to get the same quality of shots wandering on my own (with rest breaks) as I was able to get while standing beside the instructor. And I also got great advice from some of the people I randomly ran into, wandering just like me.

So I am rethinking the role of photography workshops in my future. I suspect there won’t be any more, particularly if physical limitations prevent me from fully participating. And while I fully support any talented photographer asking a fair fee for sharing their knowledge, all the scouting efforts, planning and logistics, it’s more difficult to swallow a fat fee when the experience is the one I had this last week. So I encourage anyone who is a workshop instructor to really be clear about what they are offering, and to be a bit more honest about it in their advertising. And maybe do some pre-work with each group, to find out what each individual might need.

That said, the experience of being in that environment last week was fantastic. I fully plan to go back next year.

title: What Color Would a Death Valley Artist Paint a Pupfish in Love?
content: }" data-image-title="Artist’s Palette 9 P" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-9-p.jpeg?w=300" data-large-file="https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-9-p.jpeg?w=1024" src="https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-9-p.jpeg?w=1024" alt="" class="wp-image-32834" srcset="https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-9-p.jpeg?w=1024 1024w, https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-9-p.jpeg?w=2048 2048w, https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-9-p.jpeg?w=150 150w, https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-9-p.jpeg?w=300 300w, https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-9-p.jpeg?w=768 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" />

}" data-image-title="Artist’s Palette 8 P" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-8-p.jpeg?w=300" data-large-file="https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-8-p.jpeg?w=1024" src="https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-8-p.jpeg?w=1024" alt="" class="wp-image-32833" srcset="https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-8-p.jpeg?w=1024 1024w, https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-8-p.jpeg?w=2048 2048w, https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-8-p.jpeg?w=150 150w, https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-8-p.jpeg?w=300 300w, https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-8-p.jpeg?w=768 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" />

}" data-image-title="Artist’s Palette 7 P" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-7-p.jpeg?w=300" data-large-file="https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-7-p.jpeg?w=1024" src="https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-7-p.jpeg?w=1024" alt="" class="wp-image-32832" srcset="https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-7-p.jpeg?w=1024 1024w, https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-7-p.jpeg?w=2048 2048w, https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-7-p.jpeg?w=150 150w, https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-7-p.jpeg?w=300 300w, https://peripateticbone.files.wordpress.com/2022/05/artists-palette-7-p.jpeg?w=768 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" />

Now, let’s get back to the question raised in the Headline: Assuming an artist is in Death Valley has a full palette of colors, which one would he choose to paint a pupfish in love? Enquiring minds want to know.

But first, some background. You’ve probably heard of pupfish. There are several species scattered in locations around the National Park. Once upon a time they were happy residents of a huge lake that filled Death Valley. Lake Manly was a result of the Glacial Age. When the glaciers retreated to the far north and mountain tops 10,000 years ago, the lake was left to dry up and the pupfish were left scrambling for any remaining bits of water left, like individual springs. Lack of any contact created a number of subspecies.

The ones I will feature today live in Salt Creek. Their much more famous cousins live outside of the the Valley proper in what is known as Devil’s Hole, a 430 foot deep hole in the ground filled with water. What makes them so famous is that they are a critically endangered species. Today, there are less than 100 left. There were more in the 1960s but even then they were rare enough to be declared an endangered species, one of the first species to be so, seven years before the bipartisan passage of the Endangered Species Act of 1973.

Environmentalists the world over were ecstatic. The business people not so much. Nearby ranchers were limited in how much water they could pump out of the ground and developers in what land they could sell. Profits would be reduced. All that to save a tiny fish from extinction. A “Kill the Pupfish,” “Save the Pupfish” bumper sticker war ensued. National headlines were created and people across the country became aware of the pupfish. It is still a symbol of the ongoing battle between those who see objects primarily in terms of money and those who see them primarily in terms of inherent value. Being a lifelong environmentalist, I come down on the side of the pupfish, but I feel empathy for those whose livelihood was impacted.

Now join Peggy and me as we go in search of the ‘illusive’ pupfish of salt creek, whose males turn bright blue when they are in love, or is that lust. Either way, I’m glad that isn’t an infliction of human males.

excerpt: Geology is up close and personal at Death Valley. The Valley floor and sides, stripped free of most vegetation, can’t help but show their true colors. The most colorful place to check out these colors is along the paved one-way Artist’s Palette’s drive, which is near the Devil’s Golf Course, Gold Canyon, and Bad Water […]
